city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were HEAVENLY!  My husband and I would give them 10 stars if we could.   I lined a grill basket with tinfoil and put the chicken and some marinade into it and grilled the pieces that way.  I used dried rosemary and cut the sugar in half.  I also used low fat ranch dressing and completely omitted the salt because it just isn't necessary.  These were melt in your mouth MOIST and DELICIOUS!!  Even my 19-month-old and 3-year-old gobbled this up.  The marinade from the grill basket was also incredible poured over white rice.  EXCELLENT RECIPE!!!!!
EDIT:  I've since made this recipe on the stove top and in the oven in order to use up all the marinade (which is INCREDIBLE on rice) and both alternate methods are good by the oven is a better 2nd choice as the stove top method tended to dry the chicken out a bit but still tasted great!  I bake it with all the marinade on 450 for 20 minutes.  Melt in your mouth moist!    EDIT AGAIN:  I tried another reviewers recommendation to use Trader Joe's ranch dressing...just not that good with it.  It might be slightly healthier for you but I'm willing to splurge for the little dressing that's used and use hidden valley ranch light.  Made a HUGE difference to my family and to guests who've had it both ways.  Cut back on oil...but use flavorful ranch dressing!

text:
Very tender chicken!  I would use this marinade for chicken breasts as well.  We reserved a little of the marinade and added more ranch dressing for a nice dipping sauce on the side. UPDATE: I've made these so many times now because they're just that good.  You can cut down on the oil and substitute dried rosemary for the fresh if you don't have any on hand. I always use the sugar and 1 tsp. of salt vs. two. If you're looking to cut down on calories Hidden Valley Ranch Light Buttermilk Dressing works great with this recipe.  I usually marinate this at least 6 hours. No matter what you do - it's bound to come out moist and delicious.

text:
This was fabulous!  Based on other reviews, I cut back the olive oil to 1/4 cup and omitted the salt and am glad I did.  Threw fresh rosemary twigs (soaked in water for 1/2 hour) in the smoker while barbequing these and the aroma, oh my, the aroma!  If I was Italian I would be kissing my fingers.  Momma Mia!!!  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
WOW! These were fantastic! Even my 19-month-old gobbled these up! The only ingredient I left out was the salt. I made one batch of marinade for the chicken and another batch to marinate vegetables...onions, portabello mushrooms and quartered new potatoes (about 2 lbs). After you quarter the potatoes put them in a microwave safe dish and add 1/2 cup water. Microwave on high for 13-15 minutes, just stir halfway through cooking time. Otherwise the potatoes would never be done on the grill at the same time as everything else on the skewer! After microwaving let them cool a little and then marinade.  I marinaded everything in a couple of ziploc bags for about 2 hours.  We will definitely make this again and again!

text:
These kabobs are flavorful, juicy & fabulous! Followed the recipe almost exactly and used fresh rosemary, except I took a hint from other reviewers and cut back on the salt a little bit.  I also marinated red & green peppers, sweet onions and mushrooms with the chicken, reserving a little of the marinade to use for basting. It took a little time to thread everything on the skewers and a bit messy, but it was so worth it! Next time I'm going to try putting things on the skewers first, then marinate. These would be wonderful to make ahead for a party or any kind of get-together!

The vinegar and lemon juice really tenderizes the meat, and the flavors go very well together.  Trader Joes has the best ranch dressing I have found so far (no affiliation).  It's organic, all natural ingredients, uses real buttermilk, has no high fructose corn syrup, has less fat than regular ranch, super creamy, and tastes great.

text:
I made this for 100 people last weekend, for 80 people the weekend before and for 70 the weekend before that.  I can't tell you how many asked for the recipe and how many said it was the best meal they'd ever had.  I marinated whole chicken breasts for about 6 hours.  I took them out of the marinade, scored them lengthwise several times and grilled them on a gas griddle.  When they were done, I cut them in strips and put them in an electric roaster with the marinade.  I let them slow cook on low heat for about and hour and a half.  Served over white rice with the marinade as a topping gravy.  Broccoli with garlic butter and cashews and a roll.  Beautiful plate, wonderful meal!

text:
This recipe intrigued me because it was different from any chicken dish I have tried.  I printed the recipe and planned on preparing - but the weekend got very busy (hence - no cooking!)  Sunday I was going to be gone until past dinner - I ask my husband if he would mind preparing the dish.  I left the recipe and all ingredients sitting on the counter.  The results were amazing!  Kids loved it- the chicken was tender and flavorful, and husband was proud declaring  this would now be his signature dish that he would make anytime (yipee!)  The only thing I know he did different was to use white wine vinegar instead of white vinegar.  I'm not sure why and I don't believe it really mattered.   Can't wait to invite friends over and have hubby wow 'em!

text:
This was really good. I did cut the chicken into chunks, but instead of skewering/grilling, I baked them in the sauce (20 min/350*), then served with the sauce over garlic butter rice. A couple of notes: 1. I noticed some people commented that the rosemary taste is too strong. If you're using dried rosemary instead of fresh, remember to cut the amount in half (if you don't like a noticeable rosemary flavor, you should consider cutting it more). 2. I noticed a lot of people said they ommitted the sugar. In my mind, that sweet edge pushed this recipe over the top.

text:
DELICIOUS & MOIST, even tho' I reduced the oil to 2-3 Tblsp.!! I did marinate it for 18+ hours to ensure the meat was infused with the fresh rosemary & other flavors. Excellent!  I've made this several times in several ways in the past 2 months: I've used bottled Hidden Valley, dry ranch mix, & AR's "No-Guilt Zesty Ranch Dip" (a lowfat dip from this site) - ALL were terrific. With the latter, I combined: 1/3 c. of the NG Zesty Ranch + 1/3 c. buttermilk + double the rosemary + increased all other ingredients by 50% (incl'g chicken; only 2-3 Tbl oil!) = excellent, & comparable to orig. recipe. For the pkt of dry "Simply Organic Peppercorn Ranch", I mixed: 1 Tblsp. dry mix + 1/16 tsp. dry onion powder + 4 Tbl. buttermilk + 1-1/2 Tblsp. each of mayo & sour cream = ranch dressing; then added all the other ingredients. I highly recommend any of these methods for a truly delicious grilled chicken kabob! ** UPDATE: Last time,  I skewered the chicken on stalks of the rosemary plant. I left the leaves on top, while deleafing the skewer part. I don't know if this added more rosemary flavor, but it did make for a beautiful, rustic presentation of the kabobs.

text:
So simple and so good!
I did AS IS, and don’t think I would modify it.  When these babies hit the BBQ, the smell was heavenly.  The chicken was moist, tender and the rosemary really came through.  My two little ones gobbled their portions up.  The combination of all the ingredients was spot on!
If I had to change anything, I would experiment with different brands/types of ranch dressings.  Since it is a prominent part of the recipe, I am sure that one could find nice little twists for this great recipe.  Although marked as optional, I added half of the proposed sugar, which I will leave out next time.  Also, I would not marinade much beyond an hour or the lemon juice and vinegar would start over tenderizing the chicken.

text:
Very moist and tasty!! I marinated the boneless chicken breasts in a homemade ranch dressing yesterday morning. I used, “Ranch Dressing II,” from this website. After reading other reviews regarding the salt, I decided to cut back to 1/4 teaspoon. I also cut the worcestershire sauce down to 1T and white sugar to 1/2 T. The lemon juice and herbs really made the dressing burst with fresh flavors. It was also the buttermilk from the ranch dressing that really helped tenderdize the chicken meat. The grilling time was approximate. The golden brown sear on the chicken left a carmelization -very nice. The chicken meat was so tender and juicy, not tough or dry! It  was seasoned perfectly with a good hint of the fresh rosemary -delicious! Loved it! I am so glad that I cut back on the amount of salt and marinated it for 24 hours. We all really enjoyed our kabobs. I would make it this exact same way again. I served this with, "White and Wild Rice Pilaf," also from this website.

text:
made this for dinner last night & hubby loved it so much he cleaned his plate with a spoon to get every delicious drop of this delicious sauce!!  Only changes I made were to reduce the salt to 1 tsp. instead of 2 tsp. (per other reviewer's advice -- Thx!)  and we ended up having to bake it (at 350 for 20 minutes) as a HUGE thunderstorm came up just as we were getting ready to warm up the grill, but I can't WAIT to try it on the grill next time!  Next time, I'll reduce the oil by a little (maybe 1/4 cup) and divide the marinade into 2 batches, to marinate some veggies for the skewers too!  (maybe onion, red/green bell pepper, yellow squash/zuchinni, etc).  I'm also going to try substituting this sauce for the usual Cream of ... soup in my favorite Chicken Casserole recipe.   Oh! would also be good as a Seafood Casserole, marinating shrimp, scallops, etc. in this and adding a little rice and topping with some dried bread crumbs!  REALLY REALLY GOOD SAUCE!! Thx for the recipe Theresa Spencer!

text:
Oh my. This is stellar. I am a beginner cook and even I made this dish turn out superb. The combo of ingredients is a bit odd but it sure works well when cooked. My only changes were to reduce the salt and oil by half. I do not have a grill so I baked the chicken on 350 for 20 minutes and then broiled it for a few minutes to crisp it a bit. As suggested by others, I also marinated and baked a separate pan of onions and red bell peppers (cut into chunks) - also baked and then briefly broiled.  Thank you Allrecipes.com and Theresa Spencer for this amazing recipe.  Update:  I mixed and marinated the chicken and veggies in two zip lock baggies. I lined my two baking pans with heavy duty reynolds wrap. Clean up was a breeze,

text:
Succulent and just plain scrumptious, these tender morsels of chicken will definitely grace my table again!  I used light ranch dressing, a little less oil, and very little additional salt.  I thought that I had fresh rosemary in the fridge but I did not.  Not being a huge fan of dried, I used fresh oregano instead and it was very tasty.  I am certain that rosemary would have been a better choice, however, and I cannot wait to make them again with the prescribed herb.  I was afraid that marinating for only 30 minutes as the recipe dictated would not be enough for either flavor or tenderizing but I got a late start with dinner and it was all I had.  I need not have worried; the chicken was so delicious that we all went back for seconds and, truth be told, resisting a third helping took some willpower.  Great recipe!

This is FAB!  I was looking everywhere for the perfect summer dish to whip up for my mom's birthday and after reading the reviews I knew I couldn't go wrong.  It is so easy and SO delicious!!  I opted to use 1/3 cup of oil instead of 1/2 cup like many suggested and made a separate bowl of marinade for veggies. city:

None
text:
This was some pretty good tasting grilled chicken. It reminded me of chicken from a Greek restaurant. I had planned on making it before I realized it needed to be grilled, so I cooked it in the house. I used Marzetti lite ranch dressing and dried rosemary. My bottle said 1 tsp. dried equaled 1 Tblsp. fresh. I also used about 1/2 the black pepper suggested. But, as it gave me mild heartburn, I wish I would have left it out entirely. I had med/large chicken tenderloins and used 12 and it was perfect for the amount of marinade I had. I sprayed a square cast iron grill pan with pam and heated it on 6 for 10 minutes, then grilled 4 at a time, as is without skewers, 6 minutes per side flipping once. It tasted just like grilled chicken outside. The only downside was it was a tad salty, but it was juicy.

text:
AWESOME!!! Super easy, uses ingredients typically on hand and YUMMY! I prefer brown sugar for the (optional) white, it caramellizes better on the grill. I now also increase ranch 1/4 cup and do as another reviewer suggested, make 2 separate batches and marinate chicken in one, and for the other, I micro 2 red potatoes 2.5 mins each, cut in about 2"chunks, marinate with onion chunks and whole mushrooms. If you do this, do chicken and veg on separate skewers cause the veg ones are done a few minutes quicker and 'shrooms would be burnt if it was all skewered together. This is now one of my absolute FAVORITE dinners! THANKS SO MUCH!!! ****UPDATE: Did the veg kabobs as mentioned above, but this time added squash and cherry tomatoes... OMG! I've made this at least once a week for the last 2 mos and NEVER repeat recipes with that kind of regularity, can't get enough of this meal!!!  SO MUCH better with fresh rosemary, but dried is good too in a pinch :)

This chicken was delicious.  I used strips of chicken breast and marinated sliced mushrooms as well, and left it all in the fridge for a few hours.  I covered the grill with foil and grilled it all, and then put it on small ciabatta loaves with some fresh mozzarella cheese.  Then stuck that in the oven until warm and melty.  Best paninis ever!  This chicken is great for sandwiches.

Update: After making this lots of times, we've found we like it best when we omit the lemon juice, vinegar, and sugar.

text:
I had seen this recipe recommended on the Recipe Exchange numerous times and decided to go ahead and try them.  After reading the reviews, I cut the salt in half and, because bottled ranch is pretty sweet, I didn't add the optional sugar.  These kabobs were SO good!  My daughter is having her 13th birthday in a little less than a month and she has requested these as part of the food at her party.  Next time I'll mix up some fresh Hidden Valley ranch dressing to use instead of the bottled stuff.  Since that dressing is less sweet, I'll add half of the sugar.  Thanks for a really good recipe!

text:
We enjoyed this different take on grilled chicken.  I cut back the olive oil to about 1 Tbs., and I had almost no flare-ups on the grill.  I omitted extra salt and used the marinade on boneless, skinless, whole chicken thighs.  After a sear on a hot grill, I moved them to the opposite side of the grid and finished cooking on low heat.  I hope there are some lefties, since I feel the chicken would be a great addition to a lunch salad.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this twice. The first time I grilled it and thought it was good, but not great. Chicken was tender and juicy as promised, but the rosemary, which I usually like, was just too intense for me.  The second time, I took the advice of other reviewers and baked it for 20 min in the marinade to serve over brown wild rice with a little of the sauce. I did not like the flavor at all.  The rosemary was even more overpowering and it was all just a bit tangy. Definitely if cooking in the marinade you should reduce the salt.  Just to mention, since not everyone cooks with kosher salt, I'd suggest using it for this recipe if you are following it to a T because regular table salt would make it incredibly salty.

text:
This is the first review I have ever done and it is well worth it! This chicken was amazing! I doubled the marinade, I didn't cut back on the olive oil because I thought the olive oil would soak into the chicken and make it moist. I chopped up some rosemary and then I took a whole sprig and put it in the marinade and chopped up the chicken and had it in the fridge for about 2 hours. I then put them onto the bamboo skewers (after I soaked them in water) with some red onion pieces in between the chicken. I cooked them in a grill pan on my stove and they came out amazing! I wish I had taken a picture, they tasted even better than they looked. They literally just burst with flavor and melted right in my mouth. I could eat this every day and never get tired of it. After I had got home from the grocery store, I realized I forgot the lemon, so I didn't add lemon juice, but it was still as tasty as ever!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe!!  I followed the recipe for the marinade almost exactly except I did not have fresh rosemary, so I used dried. I also do not have skewers, so I did not cut up the chicken breast.  Instead I used a meat tenderizer to pound out whole breasts and then cut them in half.  I  marinated the chicken for about 3 hrs and then cooked them in a frying pan with a little oil and butter.  The chicken was extremely tender and infused with flavor.  It was great served with some fresh veggies and pasta.   Also, adding a little reserved marinade (not used to marinate the chicken) and chicken stock to the pan drippings and allowing to reduce down a bit makes a great sauce for the chicken and pasta. YUM!

text:
I have made this recipe several times and it seems to come out differently each time.  The first time I made it, it was absolutely delicious!  The second and third times it was just ok.  I followed the recipe all 3 times exactly as written so I am not sure why it came out differently.  It is very good but the olive oil flavor seems to overwhelm it a bit so I think next time I make it, I will decrease the amount of olive oil.  I forgot to note that I didn't have any fresh rosemary so I did leave that ingredient out as I don't care for the flavor of rosemary.  Overall it is still a very good recipe and I will make it again.

text:
After seeing Cookin'Mama's review, I decided to try this for our Sunday dinner. I couldn't find our skewers, so we had grilled chicken instead of kabobs. I used 1/3 cup oil and a little more Ranch dressing, only 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce, 1 teaspoon of salt, and cider vinegar instead of white, and we marinaded the chicken for about 6 hours. It was perfectly seasoned, tender, juicy, slightly caramelized edges, and a nice hint of rosemary--delicious!

None
text:
This earned three stars for our family for a couple of reasons:
First, I had pretty high expectations. It has a pretty high rating and rave reviews and as long as I have been using this site I can't recall a time when a recipe has not lived up to reviews. We were expecting to be blown away and that did not happen.
I made this exactly as penned and the ranch flavor really didn't come through for us, I even doubled the marinade. The chicken was good, of course, but just OK. There is another grilled chicken marinade on here that we had made a couple of weeks ago and we really were blown away so, that was hard to ignore. 
Besides the ranch flavor, the rosemary didn't show up either. I grow my own rosemary and was expecting that freshness to come out and it just didn't. I love trying new things, but won't waste my time on this one again, sorry!

text:
SO GOOD!!! Everyone in my family loved these and we have a variety of tastes. None of the specific ingredients are overpowering but all blend beautifully for a flavorful, savory taste. Also, the chicken is ridiculously moist given that it has no skins to keep the moisture in and is cooked over a dry heat. I do have one suggestion for anyone giving this a try for the first time: Reduce the amount of chicken or increase all the other ingredients. You don't want to be stretching too little marinade for too much chicken. (Four breasts would be perfect.)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a simple recipe with great flavor! I almost follow this recipe to a "t". What I've changed is eliminated salt completely and instead of making kabob, I cooked the cubed chicken in the oven at 375ºF, covered with foil, for 20 minutes and then remove foil and cooked for an additional 10 to 15 minutes. I served with basmati rice and vegetables. Another thing I did differently is I marinated the cubed chicken for 2 hours before cooking. If you want to use an amazing Homemade Ranch Dressing, check out Chef John's (foodwishes.com). I'll bet you'll never buy it from the grocery store again.

Display Name:
Carolyn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is so very delicious! I've made this several times, but only once grilling the chicken as kabobs. I grilled whole chicken breasts after putting them in this marinade, but you don't get much of the marinade's flavor. I also baked whole chicken breasts after marinating them and still almost no flavor. Grilling them as kabobs is definitely the way to go - trust me! They are full of flavor and they are so juicy! If it matters to anyone, we used a charcoal grill. I only had dried rosemary leaves, so I used that instead of fresh, using the correct fresh-to-dried ratio. I also doubled the marinade and used an entire pkg of chicken, which contained six chicken breasts. After grilling all of the chicken, there was enough marinade left over to use on two frozen chicken breasts we had (which we immediately put in the marinade), but we could have put a total of five or six breasts in the left over marinade. My husband and I made the kabobs for dinner with my parents and we all loved them. Please grill - you will not be disappointed!

My husband said it was the best chicken I had ever cooked.  This is HUGE bc my husband is a MEAT(as in beef) and potatoes man.  I am always looking for great chicken recipes since chicken is more budget friendly and we have a large family. I did not have the rosemary so I used Italian seasoning.  I also marinated it for at least an hour, reserving some of the mixture so I could baste the chicken as it grilled and another reserve to dip fries in.  I used foil on the grill so the chicken would not dry out.  I removed the foil just before done and placed the chicken skewers directly on the grill and basted it.  It really was juicy and flavorful.  This was a last minute meal idea so I didn't have any of the onions or peppers I would want on my grilled food, next time I will definitely add bc the sauce is so good I want to put it on everything!

userID:
12488622
Display Name:
Cynthia
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have 3 children, and they simply cannot wait for these kabobs to be cooked and on their plate. Add some caramelized pineapple rings and potato salad, and my kids are in heaven. 
I have read reviews saying that the cook enjoys the marinade sauce sooo much, they just can't bear to throw it away. I understand this because at times you feel like you are throwing away the tastiest part. However, by using the marinade, you run a high risk of getting salmonella poisoning. Raw chicken is usually covered with salmonella bacteria; most people just call it food poisoning. But, no worries, this tasty dish is easily saved. After you have marinated you chicken, take it out of the sauce, and throw that germ riddled sauce AwAy. I can hear the gasps from here. It's ok, all you have to do is make more of the marinade/sauce that you made to put the chicken; but this time, don't put chicken in. Make a single, or a double amount of sauce (Ive read that some people are making double batches to use as sauce anyway). Make as much sauce as you want, and you and my family might fill the world with "yum"s!
Another quick tip: if you are using wood or bamboo kabob sticks, you can keep them from burning on the grill by first soaking the completely underwater for an hour before you thread the chicken on them. This way you can cook your chicken all the way through so that no pink shows on the inside, without worrying if your kabob stick will burn up before the chicken is finished.

country:

text:
I've been making this recipe for a few years and just made it again last night for a potluck. Every time I make it I get rave reviews. For our tastes, we don't add the sugar or salt but pretty much do everything else as listed. (We grow rosemary in our yard so it's always fresh and handy.) For the ranch dressing, we use Hidden Valley Ranch from the packet made with BUTTERMILK. Light years better than any bottled ranch dressing. I swear it makes a huge difference. Also, grilling is the only way to go for the right flavor. And if you want to make it easier, skip cubing & skewering the chicken. We just throw chicken tenderloins in a bag with the marinade, let it sit for a couple of hours, then throw on the grill. Just as tender and flavorful. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this recipe for dinner tonight. My 9 year old daughter was crazy about it!!! She isn't always easy to please, but I wouldn't call her a classic picky eater. She likes flavor and I suspect she is on her way to being a great cook. There wasn't a bit left on her plate. We are in a rental house during our remodel, and don't have a grill. I cut the breasts into 3 strips each, skewered them, baked for 10 minutes in the marinade, tossed the marinade, put foil on a cookie sheet, then under the broiler for 10. Perfect! I did marinade longer than 30 minutes (more like 2 hours). I would definitely increase the marinade time. Nice, simple week night main dish.

userID:
8510301
Display Name:
bitterquill
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used half the oil, roughly 1/3 the salt, and three quarters of the sugar; I also used three quarters the rosemary (1 tablespoon) because I only had dried on hand, but dried is more pungent anyway so it's probably approximately the same, flavor-wise, as if I'd used the listed amount of fresh. I marinated over night. It made a delicious marinade and juicy, tender chicken. It's also very easy to put together, relatively versatile (I've done it on the grill and under the broiler in the oven, and it was very good both ways), and quite budget-friendly. This will be a part of our regular rotation for sure, with my changes, and I think it might be my favorite chicken marinade ever. Even so, I wrestled with whether to give five stars or not, since the recipe as given has easily twice the necessary oil and three times the necessary salt, and as given would be virtually inedible to me. Even my salt-and-fat-loving husband said that it had tons of flavor with the ingredients reduced. Anyway, the core recipe is awesome, but be sure to tweak quantities as your tastes and dietary needs require, and definitely marinate at least overnight to make the flavors really come together.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/995886.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed recipe almost to a tee. Would have omitted the salt, except that I used low sodium Worcestershire sauce. I probably put in 1.5 to 2 tablespoons of minced rosemary. Use a decent ranch dressing, not something cheap that tastes only of salt. Mine turned out awesome. Not a super strong taste, but had plenty of flavor for sure. TIP: Invest in a digital thermometer and pull the chicken off when it is 165 degrees in the center. If the chicken comes out dry it is not because of the marinade, it is because you overcooked it.  Dry chicken = flavorless chicken.

These were very, very good.  I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because we found the rosemary a bit overpowering. Next time I'll reduce that a little. These were amazing!! We ate it with a salad and pita bread/hummus.  I made a couple of changes just because I didn't have some of the ingredients...I used soy sauce instead of Worcestershire, Balsalmic vinegar instead of white vinegar, and a greek feta dressing instead of ranch, and dried rosemary instead of fresh. text:
Wow.  These are delicious.  You really don't taste the ranch flavor (which is fine) but they are so tasty.  Fresh rosemary is key.  Warning: the marinade looks and smells so foul I almost threw these away before grilling.  AND my husband is not very good with the grill. Still, these were delicious after cooking and looked exactly like photo.  I followed other reviewers' tips (thanks guys!) and used 1/3 c. oil instead of 1/2 c.  My picky 11 year old who is not a big fan or chicken or ranch dressing said, "mom, these are pretty good!" and finished his plate.  Will make again!  Served with rice pilaf and grilled peaches. (Update: I have also made these replacing the ranch dressing - most are full of chemicals - with plain greek yogurt and they are just as delicious!).

userID:
3482886
Display Name:
NZtoAZ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
583
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I also added some summer squash and zucchini to the marinade and grilled them on seperate skewers. The vegetables were amazing. Red peppers would be good too. The chicken was also very nice but a little light on flavor for me. I used Maries Light Ranch (which is light on fat but big on flavor) Im  a huge fan of ranch dressing, so Im thinking that next time I will regularly brush the chicken with the marinade (there was plenty) during cooking to boost up the flavor. I ended up drizzling some extra ranch dressing over the chicken to boost up the flavor afterwards, but of course that lacked the extra flavor of the rosemary and worsestershire in the marinade. I thought about cooking it in a foil lined basket with the marinade like one of the other reviewers. This would give additional flavor, but I do like the slight charring that you get from direct-grilling. I used the left over warmed chicken and squash in sandwiches with ranch dressing the next day - and they were to die for! All in all a great simple tasty recipe.

country:

text:
I've made this twice lately and it was enjoyed by all, even the little ones.  I omitted the salt and it wasn't missed and I like my salt.  I used chicken tenders instead of cubing the chicken.  I threaded the tenders onto the kebabs kind of like ribbon-candy.  Works great and cuts out some prep time. I used fresh rosemary but really didn't taste it so I think that I will add more next time.  For everyone concerned about the sodium, remember that the nutrition information is for the chicken and the marinade, when in fact most of the marinade is discarded so one is not getting near as much sodium as it appears.

My family and I really liked this recipe. I have to give it 4 stars because I made some changes that I thought made it better. I cut the olive oil and salt measurements in half, used rice vinegar instead of white, omitted the sugar, and used boneless chicken thighs instead of breasts. I grilled the kabobs on my stovetop grill. Honestly, when I was making the marinade and tasted it I thought it was kind of gross, but the end product was delicious. It will be a regular for us!

userID:
1416920
Display Name:
Noor
isPro:

followersCount:
47
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
77
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious, very moist just as others wrote.  But I gave 4 stars because the weight of the chicken is not written.  I had 3 breasts that were one pound and 2 teaspoons of salt would have ruined them. Luckily I knew this and adjusted it to one teaspoon and they were almost too salty however we like salty food so it was good eaten with rice. I also reduced the oil to 1/4 cup and used low fat ranch. I can't imagine grilled chicken without fresh garlic so I added 2 big cloves of minced garlic.  Lastly, I used about 1 teaspoon of dried rosemary and added a dash of oregano with it and left it in the marinade for a couple of hours.  30 minutes isn't long enough for flavors to blend. Didn't have the worcestershire sauce so I left it out.  I usually marinate chicken in yogurt so this was a good alternative to the same ol and I will make it again. Almost forgot, since I was cooking with rice and someone commented on how good the sauce was and suggested cooking it in the oven under the broiler with all the marinade, I gave it a try.  But all my marinade evaporated and when the chicken was done, I was only left with the 1/4 cup oil that I added to the marinade?? I got no sauce, but the chicken browned nicely as if it were grilled outdoors.

This is an awesome recipe! The first time I used this recipe, I tasted the marinade after adding all of the ingredients, and I was very skeptical! So I added more garlic (our family loves garlic!)!  The ingredients impart an incredible flavor---even without the extra garlic! Using this marinade, we've had chicken kabobs twice, and boneless chicken breast once, and have not been disappointed. As an additional note (because it annoys me to see this in other reviews), if you do not like one or more of the ingredients in this marinade, don't try it then punish the person who put it here for us to try by giving the recipe a low rating because you didn't like some of the ingredients!

This was loved by everyone in my family of six, even earning me extra praise from my 5 yr. old: "Mom, you're best cook of all the food in the world!"

text:
I've made this recipe at least 50 times and the only changes I have ever made is, I add vegetables to the skewers, like bell peppers, onions, mushrooms, etc,  I add them to the marinade and keep them chilled until I skewer them.
 For best results, put the skewers on a hot grill, turn down the heat and cook them slow - Never over cook the chicken!
 Serve the kabobs on some rice pilaf, or, even better, a lemon Dill rice!

text:
PHENOMENAL!! I am super picky about chicken and this just became my favorite chicken I have ever eaten. I used about 4lbs of cubed chicken breasts and I let it marinade in the sauce mixture (I followed the exact recipe for the marinade) for a few hours. Then I sprayed a 9x13 casserole dish with nonstick spray and dumped the whole mixture in and baked at 400°. I probably baked it for somewhere around 45min-1hour. I didn’t time it, but I checked on it/stirred it up every 15min or so. Once I thought the chicken was cooked all the way through, I shut the oven off and left the dish in the oven for another 30min or so. It turned out perfect, tender, and super flavorful. This will definitely be a weekly meal at our home!

text:
I have made a ton of grilled chicken over the years using various marinade recipes. This recipe is hands down off the charts. The best, most delicious marinade I have ever used. Any I was not (until this recipe) a huge Ranch dressing fan. This marinade transforms not only chicken but veggies as well as serves as an excellent dipping sauce. Not that this recipe needed any adjustments but to suit my personal taste I doubled the recipe, after reading other recommendations marinaded the chicken overnight (which due to the amount of acids was needlessly slightly nervous about), added extra lemon juice, used brown instead of white sugar, added fresh garlic and thyme. THANKS for the recipe - only marinade I will use in the future.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. In the past my daughter made them, doing them as kabobs on the grill and they were wonderful. After reading some of the reviews and seeing that others had just done them in the oven and also as just breast halves and not cubes, I decided I would try that. I was in a huge hurry and all I did was dump all the marinade ingredients into a gallon zip-lock bag, shake it up,  throw in 5 chicken breast halves and let it sit for 30 minutes. Then I dumped the whole thing, marinade and all, into a shallow baking pan, covered with foil and baked at 400 for 25 minutes. Perfection! I just ate a piece of the leftover chicken and it was even better. Very moist, tender chicken with a good flavor. I followed the ingredient list exactly and wouldn't change a thing.

text:
I would have given this recipe 5 stars, but I made some changes. Both of my kids love it! (Ages 2 and 4, they both ask for seconds) I cut the amount of oil and salt in half. I've also made it three different ways, my personal favorite was in the oven. I put the marinated chicken in a glass baking dish and baked on 375 for 25 minutes. I then broiled each side for 3 minutes a piece (having drizzled some of the sauce left over in the baking dish). I wish I would have cooked a little more sauce, it's delicious to dip and put on other side items.

text:
This rosemary ranch chicken is amazing. So much so that I have made it about every other night. Yep, when the hubby eats the leftovers and we're fighting for the last piece, it's just that good. I haven't used the hidden valley ranch yet, but eventually will. I use Ken's Ranch dressing and I leave out the extra salt. I also don't use the full tbsp of sugar, just under it. I thought it was a lot of olive oil, and next time I will try it with the 1/4 cup like everyone said in the reviews.  So when I make this, I just alternate skewer fresh pineapple and chicken. I cut the pineapple to about 1/2-3/4 inch thickness and when I skewer them, I put it against the fibers, so they don't fall off when grilling (I've had it happen the first few times I made this). Hope you like it. :-) (I feel like I was in paradise eating golden pineapples and moist fragrant chicken.  Geez, talk about obsessive.. Ha-ha)

I have been making this for about a year now and realized I hadnt left a review! This is delicious, the chicken turns out sooooo tender. Love. Love. LOVE this recipe! So moist, flavorful and delicious! I omit the sugar and use red wine vinegar instead of white vinegar. I marinate overnight and am careful to only cook until they are just done to maintain moistness and flavor. text:
FANTASTIC! I followed the recipe exactly, and instead of threading the chicken onto skewers and throwing the marinade away, I baked everything in a casserole dish in the oven at 375 degrees for about 40 minutes, and served it over rice. It was a hit with the entire family. I followed this suggestion from other reviewers and I'm very glad I did. *REVISION, as we found it a bit salty (for oven version only) - reduce the salt to 1/4 teaspoon, reduce the oil to 1/4 cup, and increase the ranch dressing to 3/4 cup. Otherwise, if preparing this for kebobs, follow Theresa's recipe exactly and you won't be disappointed!

This won raves from family. I prefer listing amounts of ingredients. Chicken breasts range from 4 ounces to 16 ounces. Usually recipes call for 6 ounce chicken breasts so for this recipe that would be 30 ounces. I used 2 pounds which was 32 ounces. Perfect. 
  I did as several suggested; reduced oil, salt and increased amount of rosemary. After marinating for several hours, the chicken and marinade was put into a 400 degree oven for 20 minutes. Absolutely wonderful served on basmati rice. Next time I will add browned chopped sweet onion or bell pepper. For my portion, I will add mushrooms.  Delicious sauce.

Display Name:
CJOANC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We have made this recipe over and over and over again. I will not even eat chicken kabobs on the grill any other way now. Friends love it and always request the recipe. I usually think chicken is bland and tasteless, but these are so moist and flavorful. I cut the chicken pieces into about 1.5" cubes and then toss them in the marinade for 1-2 hours in the fridge. Even though this recipe has thousands of 5-star ratings, I always like to read the 1 and 2 star ratings just for fun. Some allrecipes users have said they bake the chicken instead of grilling, but I would think that would entirely change this recipe. IMHO, you should definitely grill these kabobs and do NOT overcook or of course they will get dry.  This recipe is not intended to be a sauce either--it's a marinade. I actually can't imagine eating it as a sauce--yuck. I do think it would be far too salty and creamy for that. Follow the recipe, folks. And if you do still find it is too salty for your likes, just omit or reduce the salt.

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe two times, both to outstanding reviews from friends.  I make this exactly as the recipe states, except I marinated for about 4 hours. It was an amazing dinner. The kabobs were moist, flavorful and totally delicious. I used Hidden Valley Ranch dressing, premium olive oil and fresh rosemary. I served with crock pot baked potatoes, side salad and bakery rosemary bread. Be sure to add additional olive oil or cooking spray to your grill because the chicken will stick. FANTASTIC! Thank you so much for sharing this recipe.

text:
Seriously, the most delicious kabobs I have ever eaten. This may be the most delicious recipe on all of allrecipes.com!
We cut the amount of chicken in half and reserved 1/3 of the marinade after we made it. (We didn't have enough Worcestershire sauce so we subbed in a couple of Tablespoons of steak sauce.) We marinated the chicken overnight, and threaded it onto the skewers along with some mini potatoes (nuked first), mini sweet peppers, and Vidalia onion. We used the reserved marinade to brush onto the vegetables during grilling.
Delicious!

text:
I used this on whole breasts baked in the oven at 450 for 30 minutes.  I simply sprayed a glass casserole dish with non-stick spray, put in the breasts and dumped on the sauce to cook!  This was absolutely the best chicken I have ever made.  It's super easy and amazingly delicious.  Even my picky 2 year old ate a WHOLE chicken breast and all his vegetables with the sauce on them!  I am planning to actually try this in a crock pot with potatoes and carrots in an almost "pot roast" style dish!

I should also note that I used Hidden Valley Ranch's dry powder and not pre-mixed ranch dressing.  I was actually out of sour cream so I went with the lower fat option of using Mayonnaise to mix the powder.  (I use Duke's Mayonnaise for mixes due to it's great flavor)and this worked out very, very well.

text:
Awesome recipe! I have made it as written and with twists and all come out great :) Recently, on a cold rainy Dec night I have made it with 4 chicken breasts cut up into bite sized pieces, half a red bell pepper, a small onion and 2 celery ribs chopped up in a 13x9 in the oven at 375 for 15-20 min and it's amazing over rice. Kids gobbled it right up. I substituted dry Italian seasoning for the rosemary in a pinch, decreased the Worcester since my daughter doesn't care for it, and decreased olive oil to 1/4c when baking, good flavor. Thanks, this recipe is a keeper, especially love that you can twist it to fit what happens to be in your pantry with great results!

text:
I made these this past weekend, and they are really good! I threaded the chicken, along with veggies (red, yellow, green peppers, cherry tomatoes and pearl onions), onto the skewers before I marinated them though. I put them into 9x12 covered glass casseroles, refrigerated and marinated overnight. My family really liked it, right down to my 3 year old grandson that wanted 2nd's! If you don't use FRESH ROSEMARY for this dish, you're simply not getting the full flavor possible here! The only change I made to the marinade mixture is that I used half the salt suggested. Thank you Theresa Spencer!

text:
I made this on a whim last night, and it was even better than expected! My mouth is watering for more as I write this. My bbq was out of propane so I just put the kabobs on a cookie sheet in the oven at 375 for about 23 minutes with a loose piece of foil over the top and it worked fine for me. The olive oil I used was infused with garlic and rosemary, but otherwise I made the recipe as written. Unfortunately my husband didn't really care for it (he doesn't like creamy sauces) but this is something I'd definitely make again for a dinner party or a pot luck when more people are there to eat them. I lightly simmered some garlic in olive oil, then stirred it into cooked white rice and served the kabobs over that. The presentation of the kabobs is beautiful, and they taste like something you'd get in a nice restaurant. 5 stars in my book!

country:

text:
I've made this twice, and it's fabulous! Instead of ranch dressing, I used plain non-fat yogurt and added  1/2 tablespoon Penzey's peppercorn dressing base. It's much healthier, plus I'm on a diet. (If you don't have a Penzey's Spice store nearby, substitute 1/2 tsp. fresh ground Tellicherry pepper, 1/2 tsp parsley, 1/4 tsp. garlic powder, 1/8 tsp thyme.) I also used a low sugar Worcestershire sauce, and left out the sugar completely - it's just not needed! I let everything marinade for an hour or two before grilling. This is my new favorite summertime chicken recipe!

text:
I used this recipe with two quite large chicken breast halves (bone in and with the skin on). I baked them at 350 degrees until they reached an internal temp of 165 degrees.  Followed the recipe for the marinade to the tee and marinated the breasts over night because they were so big.  It's not something I would make on a regular basis but for something different every now and then it was good. I added 4 peeled medium sized russet potatoes and 4 medium Walla Walla onions to the roasting pan and poured the left over marinade over them before I baked everything together. I also sprinkled some fresh rosemary leaves over everything before baking.  The potatoes and onions were even better than the chicken.

Instead of adding rosemary, I dried sprigs from my garden, and used these as skewers.  We also ran out of propane, so I broiled instead of grilling.  I added a little cayenne for some kick.  Otherwise, followed the recipe as stated.  My family really loved this!  The rosemary flavor from the skewers permeated the meat completely - I'm glad I didn't add the rosemary in the recipe.  Only use the sprigs as skewers if you really like rosemary a lot.

text:
I LOVE this one!!! It's my go-to recipe for grilling, especially boneless chicken.  I usually use boneless chicken thighs, which is inexpensive and the the dark meat is more flavorful.  It always comes out tender and juicy.  I slice it into strips.  The smaller pieces only need 3-4 minutes grilling on each side. It also works great with a George Forman electric grill. I omit the sugar and salt.  It's got plenty of flavor without those.  I now buy my ranch dressing and worcestershire sauce in the industrial sizes at a big-box store because I'm making this several times a month.  Oh, and it doesn't need long in the marinade. In a pinch, I've done for as little as 10 or 15 minutes with great results.

I loved this- but did Everyone 'Miss the line' in # 2. of Directions?
"DISCARD MARINADE".

If you are not cooking on stove in pan, or in oven, then marinade, having had Raw Meat[any kind but especially fowl] in it,- can give
you salmonella poisoning. Most of the reviews just said" I put marinade over veggies,potatos/rice. It has to be 165 degrees to kill salmonella. Ya'll Please be careful while we enjoy such wonderful,tasty treats.

text:
This was wonderful! We have a local pizza place that makes really good ranch dressing and I used it for this marinade. I made a triple batch so that i had some left over as sauce and enough for alot of chicken. Put cubed chicken into gallon sized bags then split marinade into thirds - 1/3 in each bag them 1/3 left over. Marinaded overnight and skewered the next day. Tender, juicy and delicious. Our dinner party guests said it could rival any of the Mediterranean restaurants in our metro Detroit area. Served with rice pilaf and it was spectacular. I did not put in the sugar as some other reviewers mentioned.

text:
AWESOME! Used only about 1/3 c of dressing and oil b/c I did not have any more dressing than that, cut back on all other ingredients in marinade, too. Seems like you are always dumping out marinade anyway. Glad I did, it ended up being plenty for the amt of meat.  Forgot to put in the sugar, it came out great though.  Omitted the salt, there was plenty in the dressing I figured. Used dried rosemary, only a little over a tsp of it.  Had in the marinade for approx 1 1/4 hrs or so.  The kids, who normally complain about chicken, scarfed this right down.  Will definitely make again! Soaked my skewers in H2O for a few hours but they still got burnt on the ends, oh well, no matter, the chicken was awesome.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6359594.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We LOVED this recipe! It's super-easy but it tastes like you spent the entire day in the kitchen. I used full chicken breasts instead of making them into kabobs and used Kraft Calorie-Wise 3-Cheese Ranch Dressing. I also marinated the breasts for about 5 hours, instead of 30 minutes. Next time I will add an additional TBSP of rosemary and a bit of onion powder, and marinate it overnight (refrigerated, of course). To save time, instead of mincing the rosemary by hand, put it in a food processor with the olive oil, give it a good whirl, and then add all the remaining ingredients. I hope you enjoy this recipe as much as we did!

city:

country:
None
text:
I use this marinade for my regular chicken breasts. I always cut the breast down. This way you get more flavor. If you leave them thick you end up with some bland chicken at the thickest parts. So cut the breast into 3 pieces and marinade overnight. When I place them on the grill I make sure it is a hot grill and I leave as much of the marinade on them as I can. I usually grill some corn with it and use roasted potatoes and you will have a home run! FANTASTIC flavor!

None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe and has made its way into our regular meal rotation. What we like about it the most is the flexibility. I want to begin by saying that I am not a big rosemary fan, however this recipe has the right combination of flavors that it satisfies both the rosemary lovers and those who aren't quite sure about it. The first time we made this, we made 3 batches: 1) using the recipe as written for the chicken kabobs (marinated for 5 hours), 2) omitted the vinegar and marinated vegetables (portobello, zucchini, bell peppers, onions) for 1 hour, 3) omitted the vinegar and worcestershire and used as dressing for tossed salad. I can't wait to try more variations. This is a "winner winner chicken dinner"!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/65375.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty! I soaked my skewers ahead of grilling, but the ends of several still caught fire (I'm guessing from the oil in the marinade). So if you have a choice, use metal skewers or maybe use a damp paper towel to wipe the end of the wooden skewer after you thread it. I used only 1 tsp salt instead of 2 tsp, and it was plenty. Update: I've started just marinating chicken breasts a day ahead and grilling them. I think the meat stays more juicy and tender this way as opposed to kebabs. We always make an extra batch of marinade (minus the oil and adding a bit of water) to have as a sauce. When ready to serve, I just microwave the sauce. It's excellent over both the chicken and jasmine rice. Such a delicious recipe!

This is only the 2nd recipe I've reviewed because I'm so picky... WOW this was fantastic!  Here's what I did different - as others suggested I cut the oil in half.  I used chicken tenders, lite ranch, and apple cider vinegar because that's what I had on hand.  I do think I'll cut the salt in half next time but that's just personal taste. I also baked it in the marinade at 320* for 30 mins.  The meat was so white, juicy, and moist.  I used the sauce left over from baking on top of mashed red potatoes.  I am definitely bookmarking this one and sharing!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This marinade is wonderful! I follow the directions exactly and get a great product every time!  I have made this on the grill as kabobs, and in my oven.  In both cases I make one batch of marinade for the chicken, and another for mushrooms, baby potatoes, and onions. 

On the grill I thread the veggies and the bite sized pieces of chicken. I take the extra marinade from the veggies only, and heat it through to make a side dipping sauce. 

In the oven, I cook the veggies on a large baking sheet, and the chicken in a separate container at 350 for 20 min until the chicken is cooked through and the juices run clear.  Then I take out the chicken, turn the heat up to 450 and finish the veggies for an additional 10 minutes. All of the marinade is put on the chicken, so I have lots of extra to use for my dinner!  

Prepared either way, you will wish you had more to keep for leftovers.

text:
Very good recipe....i didn't make kabobs, but just pounded chicken breasts and marinated them for about an hour.  My husband and I loved the fact that the flavor was there but didn't over power the chicken.  I omitted the salt, I didn't have fresh rosemary, so I used a little more than a teaspoon of dried, I  used light Hidden Valley Ranch and I  reduced the olive oil to 1/4 cup.  I also reduced the Worcestershire sauce to 2 tbsp because I'm not a huge fan of it, as I feel it can also be overpowering at times.  The chicken was very moist and tender.  Will definitely make again.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Rosemary Ranch Chicken Kabobs: "Rockin' chick kabobs. Tender, ranch-ey, grilled perfect! Love the rosemary." I'd never made a marinade with a creamy dressing before, so I was a little put-off by the unattractive color of it, but wow were the results awesome! (I used my fave, Naturally Fresh Lite Ranch.) I added some zucchini, bell pepper and red onion to the skewers and dribbled what was left of the marinade over them. The chicken was definitely the star of the meal though - truly amazing.

It's a pretty foolproof recipe. I have even prepared and froze a bunch ahead of time and grilled them the second night of camping.

text:
This is an excellent recipe. The only changes I made to the ingredients was that I used half a packet of ranch dressing mix and 1/4 cup of sour cream in place of bottled ranch dressing, and I used apple cider vinegar instead of white vinegar. As for preparation, I did not grill kabobs but instead baked the breasts whole. I poured the marinade over the chicken and covered the pan with foil, and baked at 350 degrees F for 30 minutes with the foil cover off during the last ten minutes of cooking. The marinade made an excellent sauce. My husband was still talking about how delicious this chicken was when we went to bed! I will definitely make this again and will absolutely try them grilled.

text:
I sandwiched red pepper between the chicken chunks on the skewers, and used some cut up steak I happened to have in the freezer as well. I must say, the chicken tasted a lot better with the flavors than the beef did. I had so much left over, so i kept it in the fridge to marinade for a day or two, and holy smokes was it delicious. I basically dumped the entire contents of my marinade bowl (chicken chunks and an excessive amount of ranch marinade) on a tin foil lined baking tray, and cooked it at 3:50 for 20 minutes. It turned out beautifully, and was wonderful on rice. Definitely an easier and saucier alternative to the skewers.

Revising my original 4 star review to make it 5! This was great! I doubled the sauce (but only used 1/2 cup oil) and marinated the chicken in it for about 30 hours in the fridge. I used some of the sauce to marinate veggies separately (GP, onion, zucchini, & potatoes), and reserved about a cup of it to brush on the kabobs as they were cooking. I used Nikkib's advice about potatoes, and after I microwaved them I marinated them for about 1 hour with the rest of the veggies. Will make again!

text:
OMG! This is absolutely amazing! I followed the recipe (except reduced salt by 1/2 tsp) and it turned out delicious! I also marinated onions, peppers (red, green & yellow), sections of asparagus, mushrooms, and baby red potatoes with the chicken, and then made the kabobs. My grill was running out of gas, so it took about 30 to cook (so it was really low heat), but I would be tempted to slow cook them again. Loved the baby red potatoes with it. Made up some white rice by using chicken broth instead of water, and then set the kabobs on the rice right off the grill, to season the rice. I also had put the remainder of the marinade on some foil on the grill just to cook it, and then poured that over the kabobs and rice. Holy smokes. :) So good! Packed with flavor and tenderness. Better than anything you can get in a restaurant. THIS IS PROBABLY MY FAVORITE MEAL NOW! FABULOUS!!!

text:
Very tasty! Made this tonight, but didn't use skewers. I lined a broiler pan with foil, then I marinated veggies with the cubed chicken (Baby Bella Button Mushrooms, Red Onion and Green Pepper chunks and Cherry Tomatoes) for 1 1/2 hours then put all in the pan and placed on a high heat grill for about 25 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes or so. Served over white rice that I make using chicken broth instead of water and season with parsley, garlic & onion powder and white ground pepper. I also added garlic & onion powder, white ground pepper and Island Breeze seasoned salt to the marinade (omitted the white salt). The chicken and veggies cooked well this way and had that grilled flavor even though they never really touched the grates! Hubby loved it! Will go on my dinner rotation. Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
1531135
Display Name:
Samplfamily

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4472279.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe!  My entire family LOVED it!  We have made it many times and here are a few of our misadventures.  Don't over marinade!  30 minutes is all you need the texture of the chicken will change if you go too long (from the acidity of the lemon I think).  Fresh rosemary is the only way to go...it tastes completely different with dried rosemary.  We forgot fresh one time and were very disappointed with the dried version.  For some reason the way to get the best taste is on the BBQ, we tried other ways of making it and it was not as good.  Don't mess with the original recipe, it is really awesome the way it is!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-03-04T14:39:20.753
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2480023
Display Name:
Susan Gimbut

text:
This was sooo good.  I marinated the chicken for 1 hour, and I decreased the amount of salt to 1/2 teaspoon.  It could have used a tiny bit more salt, but I feel that 2 teaspoons would have been way too much.  The sugar was a little lagniappe that I felt was a very nice, subtle addition to the recipe.  I grilled the skewers for ~9 minutes on a grill preheated to 400 degrees, turning occasionally.  The chicken came out very juicy and tender.  Next time, I might try a different herb to see how the flavor compares...oregano, thyme, cilantro.  Mmmm, they all sound great.

5 stars - I loved this recipe!  I had a package of 4 chix breasts and all the ingredients for the marinade.  I chopped fresh rosemary like it called for and it was the perfect hint of flavor.  The vinegar definite helps keep the chicken breast moist, so don't leave it out. Cider vinegar would also work...  For a side, I made stir fried green beans with bacon bits and red onion.  This was a great low-carb meal... next time I will use fat-free ranch dressing!

text:
I thought this chicken was awesome!  Fabulous marinade.  I didn't do this as kabobs, just some chicken breasts.  But I probably would do the kabobs the next time and marinade some vegetables for the kabobs also. I think the key to this recipe is you have to grill the meat.  I read some other reviews and it seems like the people who baked the chicken did not like it as well.  I think the grilling method really kicks up the chicken flavor and marinade a notch!  I am planning to make this the next time I entertain.  I think people would be surprised whats all in the marinade.  I wasn't expecting such a huge flavor from the ranch dressing!

Absolutely Incredible Recipe. Followed the recipe to the letter for the marinade, except for marinading for 4 hours. I made an extra batch of marinade to use while cooking and for dipping. text:
This is FANTASTIC!  We just finished dinner and everyone raved about it...even the veggie haters. The flavor is TO DIE FOR! After reading other reviews, I doubled the marinade and used half for the chicken and the other half for zucchini, mushrooms and red potatoes.  I quartered the potatoes and microwaved them as another reviewer suggested before tossing them into the marinade.  Two hours later, everything went onto skewers and then into the oven at 425 degrees for about 20 minutes.  Everyone raved!  And, the pan juices were great drizzled over the chicken, vegetables and rice.  A definite keeper!!

I will be serving these again and again!

These were a hit at my BBQ last night.  Everyone gobbled them up! I only added 1 tsp of salt, completely left out the sugar, and marinated them for over two hours. I used chicken tenders instead of cutting chicken breasts into cubes. I weaved the tenders onto skewers without cutting them. I then placed them on the grill for 10 minutes, turning them once. They were absolutely delicious.  Many of my guests asked for the recipe. I will make these again for sure!

text:
What a simple yet AMAZING marinade! I used all the ingredients with the exception of the rosemary (which I had none of and replaced with Mrs. Dash Garlic and Herb seasoning) and the white vinegar (which I replaced with Red wine vinegar infused with garlic.) I marinated them for 3-4 hours and I think that made them so perfect.They were awesome! So moist and tasty! My hubby is not a big fan of kabobs of any sort yet he has already requested these again! I think this time I will take some others advice and add some veggies (mushrooms, onions, peppers) in with the marinade. This recipe is a keeper for sure! Update: The second time I made these they were just as perfect as the first, even my extremely picky brother-in-law loved them. I made a second batch of marinade using half the amount of each ingredient and placed in it baby bella mushrooms and green pepper chunks. Amazing! Use this recipe!

text:
I have never reviewed a recipe on here before, but felt the need to on this one, it was so GOOD!  Like others, I omitted the salt and cut the sugar in half.  Also, did not have apple cider vinegar on hand, so used regular white vinegar and red wine vinegar.  Doubled the sauce for 6 skinless chicken breasts and I parboiled the breasts in chicken broth. We were taking to lake to cook and did not want to bother with the raw chicken out there.  Used mushrooms, tomatoes, green peppers and purple onions.  They were absolutely delicious!  Will most definetly be making these often this summer.

country:
None
text:
This was great. Reminded me of a stroganoff. I made it in my slow cooker.

I marinated for a little over an hour then threw it all into my slowcooker. I used 3 good sized breats. To use more chicken, I'd double the sauce. I added 1 tablespoon of onion powder and did use a good tablespoon of sugar which is called for as being optional.

I cooked it on low for probably 4 hours and stirred it occasionally. When it was looking done I mixed equal parts of a tablespoon of cornstarch and water to thicken the sauce. 

Served it over noodles. Delicious combo of ingredients.

I'm planning a cook out for my hubby's b.day. He wants ribs, chicken AND salmon for the main courses - I wanted something guests could easily pick up to munch on or sit down and eat as well - so I decided to do some kabobs for the chicken. I thought I'd try several different recipes to see which one he liked the best. I was afraid he would want to do them all, as you can see he likes choices! I made this Rosemary Ranch one, Hawaiian Chicken Kabobs, Chicken Kabobs Mexicana, and Yummy Honey Chicken Kabobs. For lunch today we had one of each as a test... following all recipes exactly and marinated each one overnight. This one was definitely the best! Chicken was much more tender, juicy, and full of flavor compared to the other ones. Too bad it had the most calories/fat - but hey it's for a party!

text:
Have made this a few times now and we really like it. Served to company tonight and got compliments. Kids and adults both like it. My only advice is to skewer the chicken first and pour marinade over the meat on a cookie sheet or similar pan (the chicken is too slippery to skewer easily if marinated first). Turn the skewers to coat the meat. Oil the grill so the meat doesn’t stick too. Enjoy!

text:
This was very tasty!!  I used 1/4 cup olive oil, closer to 2 Tbs. Worc., dried rosemary that I crushed in a mortar/pestal, and 1 tsp. salt. Using Hidden Valley Ranch dressing I thought it was still a bit too salty for our taste so next time I might omit the additional salt altogether. I didn't have time to cut and thread the chicken on a skewer so I just pounded and cut the breasts in half and grilled them.

text:
This recipe is freaking awesome!!!! I cooked it in the oven rather than over flame and it turned out amazing...

What I did was also skewered green peppers and tomatoes, made it all in the oven (cooking at 400 for about 25 minutes), placing the skewers on a Pyrex bowl to keep 'em elevated - and then dripped the run off leftover sauce from the chicken mixture after it was cooked onto the veggies and a little back on the chicken and served it.. 

OH MY god was it awesome. Best. Kabobs. Ever.

Thank You, Theresa!!!!!

text:
This has become a regular in our mealtime rotation. All 5 of us in our family love it - even my pickiest kiddo! I omit the sugar and double the marinade. I add mushrooms, zucchini, and bell pepper to the mix and let it marinate for a few hours if there’s time. I boil the marinade after I pull everything out and place them on skewers and we drizzle it over the top when eating. We eat it atop caluiflower rice and it’s a healthy, very yummy meal!

text:
Used alittle extra Worcestershire sauce and lemon juice.
Didnt have fresh rosemary so I used alittle more than called for of dried rosemary leaves.

I slathered 3 chicken breast cut in half length wise (6 pieces) with half of sauce, let sit for about 30 minutes and baked on 400°f With foil cover for 20 minutes took off foil and added rest of sauce and cooked for about 25-30 minutes. (Cooked alittle too much but I was multi tasking and it wasn't burning)

Sweet with subtle rosemary taste.

text:
I made this twice in the past three weeks.  Like most I left out the sugar and halved the olive oil.  First time around was great but seemed a little bland.  This past weekend was for a group and I added 1 tablespoon Dried Rosemary, and 1 teaspoon of Dry Mustard which gave a little kick.  I still halved the olive oil and left out the sugar.  Fantastic!  Everyone wanted the recipe.  
Also recipe will do 3-5 chicken breasts so multiply ingredients as you increase the chicken.  Also marinated about 12 hours.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I baked this in the oven like some other reviewers. They said to bake it at 350 for 20 minutes in the sauce. I put mine in a 9x10 pan and it was still raw on the outside after 20 minutes. At 40 minutes it was cooked but not hot so I baked my bite size pieces 50 minutes total. In the end, this chicken was edible but I didn’t like it. It didn’t have much flavor and tasted kinda like roast turkey. I wouldn’t make it this way again. I gave this recipe 4 stars because I have made it on the grill before and it was good  I just don’t recommend oven baking it.

text:
5.18.2018 - These were excellent! Very easy and quick to make. I did reduce the salt in half and think it could be reduced to 1/2 tsp depending on the ranch dressing you're using. The marinade ingredients are not overpowering at all and results in moist and a good flavor for the chicken.  Definitely not bland kabobs. We skewered the chicken along with bell peppers and tomatoes. Will be making this recipe again! Thanks for the recipe! 5.27.2018 - Made these again to be Lactose Free by making a vegan ranch dressing (from Karissa's Vegan Kitchen website). The kabob's were delicious and we felt they were much better using the vegan dressing instead of Hidden Valley Ranch.  Great recipe and one we'll definitely continue to make.

userID:
5013815
Display Name:
ljayess
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5010679.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WoW! This was a huge hit tonight at dinner. I heard the declaration, "this is so good!" with nearly every bite from all sitting at the table.  It really is that good!  I didn't have enough prepared ranch dressing on hand, so I whipped up a batch using a ranch dressing packet mix I had in my pantry. I also cut the salt down to 1/4 teaspoon since the ranch dressing mix was pretty high in sodium. I made a triple batch of marinade. I put chicken breast tenders in one bag and mushrooms, onion, and sweet red pepper pieces in another. After a few hours, I skewered it all and put it on the grill.
Don't be tempted to cut back on the rosemary or the sugar because the addition of those flavors are what make it so special. This really is an "impress the company" type of dish!  Be sure to make more than you think you need because they'll be going back for seconds and thirds. The leftover chicken would also be delicious the next day sliced up on a salad with some arugula and diced hard-boiled egg.

text:
These were very good.  After reading the reviews, I decided to cook in a grill pan to enjoy the marinade, but at the end it really separated and was quite oily.  I had even cut the oil in half.  I may have cooked them a little longer than needed, but wanted to make sure they were done.  The only other change I made was to use dry rosemary since that was all I had and cut the salt in half as well.  I used low fat ranch because I wanted to keep the calorie count down.  I poured the marinade over rice and it was good that way.  It would probably be good over mashed potatoes too.

userID:
14235906
Display Name:
Nashen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
428
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4507945.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really easy and excellent meal. I mixed up the marinade with a little less sugar than called for, also subbing brown sugar for white because that's what I had on hand. I had frozen chicken breasts in the freezer so the night before I put them in a ziplock bag with the marinade while still frozen. I put this back into the refrigerator to defrost in the sauce. The next day I periodically massaged the bag. An hour before cooking this for dinner, I soaked the skewers in a baking dish of water and I took the chicken out to cut into bite-size pieces. I noticed the marinade had gotten a bit watery from the chicken defrosting so I made a small extra portion of it and added it to the bag. Then I tossed the cut pieces of chicken back into the bag with some cut up broccoli. We grilled this over coals alongside some veggies skewers and a basket of the marinated broccoli. Throughout the grilling process we poured extra sauce from the bag over the chicken and vegetables. This was tender, tasty and easy to prepare. Will make again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-04-14T14:58:54.177

text:
This came out excellent! Very tasty, and actually tasted like a mediterranean kabob dish. I actually used the broiler in my oven (live in an apartment, so no grill!). I set the broiler at 450 degrees, with the heating element 4-5 inches away for about 5 minutes each side. I had to do an additional 5 minutes to get that charred crispy texture. Super good. I tried this because I was tired of doing the same chicken recipes and wanted something different. Thanks so much to whoever posted it!

text:
This has to be some of the tastiest chicken kabobs I have made.  The rosemary and ranch, along many of the other ingredients provide a great flavor palate that you can taste off of the grill.  I used four large chicken breasts from Costco and they were the perfect size for this recipe.  I have plenty of fresh rosemary bushes planted around the house and it was just the ticket for the fragrant flavor rosemary provides.  Happens to be one of my favorite herbs I use for cooking.  The kabobs were tender and juicy as I grilled them for 6 minutes on each side.  This will be a family favorite for sure.

text:
Made this tonight. Only marinated for 15 minutes (time constraint, no Worchestershire Sauce! Waited for hubby to bring some home.) Used some chicken breast tenderloins and some boneless thighs. Baked in oven with some quartered red potatoes and carrots (which roasted while meat marinated.) A huge hit with the whole family. Husband initially voiced concern because he does not like hot ranch dressing. My 7 year old does not like ranch dressing (neither do I, but I have enjoyed things with ranch - not salad - so this sounded yummy!) so we served it without telling him what the marinade/sauce was. He loved it! Hubby loved it. Very good., moist and tasty! Can't wait to marinade longer and grill, per recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this dish. It delivered on the promise to be moist and juicy. I did a few things a little different - based purely on personal taste. I cut the salt as well as the rosemary in half. Also next time I would use a little less oil as the mixture seemed to be swimming in oil. I also used white wine vinegar in place of plain white vinegar. I think next time I would also add some chili flakes or a dash of favourite hot sauce as I like a little extra oomph. But overall, I was very happy with this recipe.  We diced up the chicken and placed on top of a salad and really enjoyed the results. Thank you for sharing.

text:
This is one of my family's favorites.  I make it quite regularly following the recipe exactly as found here except I don't add the optional sugar and I marinate the chicken for several hours.  I've made it both with cut up cubed chicken and also with full chicken breasts.  Both ways are good, but I'd say that it's slightly better with chicken cubes.  Personally I hate skewering things so I just get a grill pan with holes in it and grill it on that.  Works just as well and is half the trouble of skewers.  Overall this is a fantastic recipe that I'm happy to have in my menu rotation.

text:
This was a really great dish I grilled up for July 4th celebration.    But it would be great anytime.  I picked it because it seemed quick - and it WAS!  I marinated the cut chicken in the early morning in a plastic bag and by evening when I grilled the Kabobs they were very tasty and tender.    I reduced the oil by half and added a bit more ranch dressing to make up the difference.    Even the picky eaters loved it - I made a LOT for everyone - I had only one kabob left over!  It went really fast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read reviews and made the following changes.  To the marinade used 1/4 c olive oil, 1 1/2 T W. Sauce, 3 T Rosemary, 1/2 t salt, 2 t lemon juice and used 1/2 marinade on chicken and 1/2 marinade on veggies, fresh mushrooms w/stems - halved, green and red bell peppers, cut into 1 1/2" pieces, large Vidalia onion cut into 1 1/2" pieces and let set in refrig. for 4-5 hours, then threaded all on skewers.  Preheated electric grill to med. high heat and cooked for 15 minutes turning 1/2 way through.  This came out excellent for a 4th of July cookout.  Thanks for the recipe and for the great reviews!  Will make again...

text:
These came out great! I followed the ingredients and instructions in the recipe exactly. I combined the ingredients in a Ziploc bag so I could shake everything up really well.
I minced up the rosemary and added it to the marinade, but I also stuck the entire rosemary plant in the bag while it marinated.
Grilled on skewers and flipped when appropriate. About 10-12 minutes total on the grill @ med-high temp.

region:

country:
None
text:
Delicious!! I cut back that olive oil by 1/4 after reading some other reviews. Then I cut the chicken up, tossed it with the marinade in a ziplock bag, and let it sit in the fridge all day so that it really soaked up the flavor. After I put all the chicken and veggies on the kabob, I used the excess marinade in the bag to coat the veggies (red and yellow pepper, zucchini, yellow squash, and sweet onion). Next time I hope to have some fresh rosemary; all I had on hand at the time was dried.  But still, everything came out so flavorful!  I judge how well a recipe turned out by how long the leftovers last in the fridge--these were gone by the next day.

text:
Theses were so good that even my pickiest eater asked for seconds. I omitted the sugar, substituted coconut aminos for  the Worcestershire and used my homemade ranch in order to make these Whole 30 compliant (sugar free). I added some veggies (bell peppers, red onions, and zucchini) and assembled the kabobs before covering them in the sauce to make them easier to prepare and less messy. I grilled them on my gas grill on a few grill mats and they came out perfect and full of flavor. I have already made these 3 times, each time making a bigger batch as they don't seem to last long around my house. Thanks for the great recipe! I love when I find things that can be easily adapted to fit my dietary needs.

text:
I've had my eye on this for a while now, I'm so glad I finally decided to try it! 
I had 8 chicken breasts which I decided to just flatten a bit and keep whole instead of kabobs. 
I doubled the marinade but only used 1/4 cup of olive oil in total. 
I Marinaded mine for 2 hours and they turned out very flavourful... And I could definitely taste the ranch 
My only suggestion is to cut the oil down by half at least.. And use a good quality ranch dressing.

text:
Well I didn't have any propane, so I didn't grill it, nor did I kebob the chicken, but it was still so good! I made the marinade in the morning and didn't cook the chicken until I got home from work, so that was at least 10-11 hours of sitting in the marinade.
Both my husband and I were pleasantly surprised at how good this was (and I'm not known for making really good food outside of a crockpot), so he's already got plans to make this again on the grill.
I did use fresh Rosemary which I think added quite a bit of nice flavor, and I agree that cutting down on the oil would be good for next time, but otherwise, it was perfect the way it's written!
