text:
This is a very tasty marinade, but I'm glad I read some reviews before making it . I cut in half both the salt and the olive oil and am glad I did. The marinade was bordering on being too salty even at half, and it was way too oily. I am going to reduce both of those quantities a bit more next time.  I had some chicken cubes and marinade left over and cooked them together the next day in the microwave. It was delicious and would probably have been very good over rice. I plan to triple the marinade next time to have enough for sauce.

text:
I didn't want to bother with the whole mess of the outdoor grill so I prepared this on my George Foreman grill.  I'm giving this 4 out of 5 because I reduced the salt to a scant 1.5 tsp. and it was still a bit on the salty side.  Next time I will try using 1 tsp. salt.  I also let this sit for longer than 30 minutes while prepping other things, so it really had a chance to absorb the flavors.  The marinade was delicious and the chicken was very juicy and tender. This recipe also makes enough marinade for  more than the 5 half breasts it calls for.  Delicious!

text:
What an awesome recipe!  I've made this a few times now with chicken breasts and thighs (both are good).  The sauce is incredible, so I recommend baking rather than grilling.  I place the chicken and marinade in a baking dish for 30 minutes, then just pop it into the oven at 450 for 20 minutes or so.  That way you get to use the extra sauce, which goes great over rice.

text:
We really enjoyed this, but we did make some changes because of  what we had on hand.

We only had 1/4 cup of regular olive oil, so added 1/4 of lemon infused olive oil.  We also didn't have quite 1/4 cup of ranch, so topped it off with Caeser. We used White wine vinegar and substituted Thyme for the Rosemary.  The chicken breast we used, was thin cut, so we grilled it as is, rather than as kabobs.  It was delicious!  We will make this again!

text:
Because it was too cold to BBQ today, I marinated the whole chicken breasts for most of the day in a large ziplock bag.  The only changes I made to the marinade were to add a little more lemon juice, omit the sugar and I used white wine vinegar instead of white vinegar.  Then I  put them in a roasting pan with the marinade and baked them at 400 for about 20 - 25 minutes.  Oh my, they were delicious and the savoury lemon sauce was perfect!  Everyone loved it!

userID:
3332143
Display Name:
Michelle21689
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made these for dinner and I have to say, I couldn't stop snacking on them after I was full! It's not like it's bursting with flavor where it hits you in the face but it's very subtle and addicting. I only marinated it for 30 minutes as instructed and it had good flavor and was pretty juicy. When I first saw this recipe and tasted the suace I thought it was odd but it does work well together. I think the important thing is how you cook it.

I didn't have a grill so I tried cooking it on a cast iron skillet which was too small and made for uneven meat. I baked some and it didn't look appealing so I just ended up throwing it all on a skillet with a bit of butter like a fajita and it was really good. I took some advice from people and only used 1/4 oil, any more I think would've been too much. I also omitted salt because everyone said it was too salty but I thought it could use a bit more, I think it depends how you marinade it. I also used buttermilk ranch, threw some veggies on the skillet with leftover marinade and served it with rice. 

Next time, the changes I would make is probably add more Rosemary, go ahead and add the salt, and just throw it on a skillet instead of skewers to save time if I'm really hungry. 

I would make it again! I have some leftover chicken marinating so we will see if it tastes even better overnight.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-11-05T11:19:25.41

text:
I've made these several times and they're in our monthly rotation now.  I don't have a grill, so I've tried the oven and stovetop.  Stove top is better.  I don't bother putting them on skewers anymore.  We have young kids and while it's a fun novelty, I got tired of sword fights :)  I do use fresh rosemary, dried just doesn't have the same flavor.  I also make my own ranch dressing, which is worth the trouble for this recipe.  It's delicious by itself or over rice.  It's a crowd pleaser and all my kids (ages 1-10) like it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for tailgating today - adding veggies to the skewer. They were wonderful. Tender and very tasty. The flavor was perfect. This recipe allows the natural flavors to come through, but at the same time makes the chicken and veggies better.  I received rave reviews from our tailgating crew.

My small changes:  I included red pepper, onion, fresh mushrooms, and small potatoes (pre-boiled) to my skewers. I used Hidden Valley Light ranch, white wine vinegar, half the sugar, half the rosemary, and no additional salt. I was worried about the rosemary overpowering the taste, but it didn't at all. Next time, I will use the regular amount of rosemary. I made the kebabs last night and let them marinate all night in plastic bags.  We will definitely use this marinade just for chicken breasts in the future too.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found out about a last minute cookout that my husband's new employer had invited us to.  After getting in from work at 2 a.m. I cut up my chicken, whipped together this marinade ( I was tired, just guessed on the measurements) and let it all sit in the fridge until about 11 a.m. which is when I put the chicken on the skewers and headed to the cookout.  After about 10 minutes they were off the grill and I was nervous, never having made this recipe before, but all of the guys LOVED them, and so did I!!  The chicken was tender, full of flavor, and a big hit!!  My husband doesn't even like rosemary but kept coming back for more!  It seems that the fresh rosemary does really give this recipe that extra boost of flavor, and I poured a little heavy on the worcestershire sauce, outcome was amazing!  If I can make this in the middle of the night, half awake without a measuring cup, and have such a hit then you can't go wrong!!

text:
This is one of my family's all time favorite recipes.  The first time I made it was for a family houseboat vacation in Lake Powell.  I quadrupled the recipe and every last piece was eaten.  I make this for family dinner at least once a month and even my pickiest eaters (I have very little kids) beg for more.  Most of the time, I use dried rosemary because I always have it on hand.  I prefer it with fresh rosemary, but dried works great too.  Do yourself a favor and make this tonight!

text:
I tried this the first time with thighs and it tasted amazing on the outside, but marinade didn't penetrate into the meat very well (it WAS nice and tender though).  You really need to have small pieces for the flavor impact, but it's well worth it because this marinade is delicious!!  The vinegar sounded strange at first, but don't leave it out.  Follow the recipe as-is and you're sure to have a winner.  If you like this chicken marinade I highly recommend a beef recipe: "Best Steak Marinade in Existence" posted by user Kookie.  These 2 are the last marinades I'll ever use!  Thanks for posting!

text:
Prepped this meal the night before an early afternoon BBQ by having the already put-together kabobs marinate overnight in the fridge. Came out beautifully and no complaints could be heard until there was none left. 
It was a little messy to cook, cutting back on the oil is a good idea. Also, rubbing together and breaking up dried rosemary a bit with your hands brings out more aroma and flavor in the marinade.

This is a very good chicken dish. It was fairly simple and my parents and sister loved it. It was a bit heavy for me so I added more lemon juice to lighten it up with the acid. region:

country:
None
text:
This is by far the best new recipe we've tried in a LONG time!!!  Even picky 11 year old could not get enough.  We reduced the salt to 1 teaspoon and used light hidden valley ranch per other reviewer suggestions. Because everyone spoke so highly of the marinade, I put one batch in a big Ziploc back with the chicken and another batch with zucchini, yellow squash, cherry tomatoes, and a red and orange pepper. Once we put the veggies and chicken on skewers I took the rest of the veggies and marinade and cooked it in a small saucepan while the skewers cooked.  WOW!!!  Super juicy and delicious.  Only problem was I made 4 huge skewers using veggies and 3 total chicken breasts thinking it would last our family of 3 a couple nights, however every single morsel of chicken and vegetables vanished! Thanks for this recipe Theresa!  We will make it often.

text:
Really great recipe. Flavorful and eat to make. I didn't use actual ranch dressing, i used 1\4 cup of ranch seasoning (the powder) and it still came out great.

**edit
I've made this recipe a lot of times and it's super yummy. I also was lazy and didn't want to put it on skewers so I just threw it into a wok. The result was a super saucy, great tasting chicken meal that we ate on a bed a rice. A1.

text:
This was absolutely delicious. I didn't have fresh rosemary, so I used dried, but the flavor came through wonderfully. I also used Brianna's Buttermilk Ranch dressing. It's a bit healthier than some of the more known  brands. I left out the worcestershire sauce and black pepper because we don't like them.
I also marinated a red pepper and baby portable mushrooms in balsamic vinegar and olive oil and garlic salt and served alongside a crisp romaine salad. Awesome, easy, delicious dinner!

text:
This was an accidental find that turned into one of our favorites.  I wanted to make the Tomato Basil Pasta from this site, and needed a protein to go with it.   After a quick search, I thought I would give this a try.  Perfect Summer combo really.  I cooked this on my indoor grill, and it was perfect.  If anything, I might cut back on the rosemary just a hair, but I probably won't even do that.  Quick and easy, and full of flavor.  This combo will be  regular Summer rotation for us on either the indoor or outdoor grill.  Do yourself a favor and don't skimp with the dried rosemary.  Go fresh for Summer!

This wasn't for me or my family. The ranch gives a weird taste with the lemon, Worcestershire, and Rosemary. I think, if I try it again, I'd use ranch seasoning, no salt, less rosemary, and less oil. I broiled it because I don't have a grill, so maybe that's why I didn't like it? They were juicy, though. I had no issue with it being seasoned and juicy and enough food/marinade. Like I said, if I try it again, I'll make some changes to make it more to my taste.

text:
I actually make this with vegetarian chicken (Quorn chik'n tenders), and it is quickly becoming a favorite! For one bag of Quorn, I use only 1/4 c oil and 1/4 c ranch dressing (I guess mine is technically Ranch dip) and then the rest as noted. I mix everything up together in a bowl, add the "chik'n," then let it chill in the fridge for a few hours before I sautée it in the frying pan. I'm sure it would be delicious grilled, but I just haven't taken the time to do that yet.

text:
I made this recipe for my family of six, and the bowl was emptied in the first five minutes!! I would double the recipe if you are making for over 5 people. I added 1/4 cup more olive oil then what was called for, and I brushed olive oil over the chicken on the grill every 2.5 minutes. I also flipped the Kabobs every 2-3 minutes. The chicken had a little less flavor then I was hoping for, so, I would marinade for 2-3 hours in the future. All-in-all this is an amazing recipe!! My family said this is a keeper!! Very good!!!

text:
This was delicious! I had to sub items out as I didn't have all on hand and it still came out ultra yummy!
- Used dried rosemary
- Omitted salt
- Used lime juice instead of lemons since that's what I had
- Used balsamic vinegar since I didn't have any white
- Used 1/4 tsp Stevia instead of sugar
Will definitely cook again!

text:
This chicken was amazing! I took the suggestion of another reviewer and baked it. I didn't have enough ranch, only about 1/4 cup, so I used about 1/4 cup of blue cheese dressing and 2 tablespoons of Caesar dressing just for fun! Also, I only had apple cider vinegar which did the job just fine. I baked the cut up chicken with the marinade for approximately 25 minutes-I made sure that each piece reached 165 degrees before taking the dish out of the oven. We ate it along with noodles and Alfredo. Will definitely be making this again!

text:
I made this with only about a lb of chicken tenders that I cut into smaller pieces. I still made the full amount of sauce; the extra would be good for dipping the chicken or marinating veggies. Since I don't have an outdoor grill, I baked them at 350 for 20 min (per some suggestions). It worked well...came out very tender. No color though so I put them on the GF grill for a few minutes. Got some nice grill marks and still tender. Thanks for the recipe, Theresa!

I ran across this, wanting something different with chicken. For over a year now, I have CRAVED this on multiple occasions!!! On the off chance you end up having leftover chicken, the next night saute some onion, garlic, celery, and carrots, add some chicken broth and cooked rice, and voilà! The best chicken and rice soup on the planet!!! If the consistency seems off, I add more ranch and sugar. Absolutely LOVE this chicken!!!

country:

text:
Wonderful!

I made sure to buy fresh rosemary from the produce department. I had dried, but I just didn't think that would do the recipe justice.  I marinated mine for about 5 hours (I always marinate longer than recipes say, just a personal preference).

I didn't bother putting the chicken on skewers, and I just cooked it on the stovetop for about 14 minutes.

I will admit-I was skeptical at first. There was a lot of marinade in the pan when I first put the chicken in, and I was worried I would have a big gloppy mess on my hands. Luckily, the marinade cooks down.  The chicken ended up being fantastic. Although I made it in the winter, it tasted like spring to me, and I can't wait to make it as a light dinner when the weather gets warmer :)

Also, I made extra and plan on throwing it into a pan of fettuccine alfredo later this week. So excited!

text:
This recipe was delicious! My fiance and I don't have a grill right now, so we baked this instead. I cubed the chicken and put it into a baking dish. I then covered it with the marinade. Then I simply baked the chicken at 450 degrees for 20 minutes. I served the chicken over a bed of rice. One thing to note- use 1/2 the recommended olive oil. If you use the full amount, it turns out way too oily! Other than that, a GREAT dish that both my fiance and I loved!

Display Name:
Ingrid Ainsworth Brown
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe. Very easy to prepare, and the chicken turns out super tender melt in the mouth, with subtle flavors that blend wonderfully. I had it marinating overnight. I used peppercorn ranch because this is what I had in the fridge, substituted dried rosemary for the fresh one and vegetable oil for the olive oil because I don't like the olive oil flavor. Rosemary flavor was very subtle. I suspect fresh herbs would give more pronounced flavor. Next time I make this recipe, I will make sure to buy fresh rosemary. After reading other reviews, I halved the salt, and I think it was the right decision. This recipe will definitely be added to my regular rotation!

text:
Incredible taste! Wow! My family raved about this - they said it was like "company dinner". :) I baked the chicken on skewers in the oven for 20 mins at 350F and then broiled them another 5-10 minutes, turning once, to give 'em a little 'char' taste. I removed the sauce after baking and served it over rice and broccoli as other reviewers recommended - very tasty!
I reduced the olive oil to 1/4 cup, the salt to 1 teaspoon and it tasted great! Highly recommend this one - you will be impressed!

This recipe was absolutely delicious, and better yet.. so simple to make!  I marinated mine for 2 days and it was well worth the wait, they were full of flavor.  Also, I cubed my chicken when it was only about half defrosted, as it is much easier to cut it into nice cubes when still partially frozen. Just tried this today after being intrigued by the ingredients.  I followed the recipe exactly as written (including the sugar) and was floored by how delicious and juicy the chicken was. text:
EXCELLENT marinade! I left the chicken soaking for probably 4 hours and about 2 hours with slightly pre-cooked potatoes, onions and raw green peppers. The meat was put on skewers for grilling and I went ahead and finished roasting the veggies (potatoes/onions first for 15-20 minutes and added peppers a little later for less cooking). Because we got distracted, I ended up taking the chicken off the skewers and just adding it to the roasting vegetables for about the last 10 minutes. It was wonderful and we can't thank you enough for the recipe! (Oh, I did omit the salt and don't feel like we missed anything.)

text:
**EDIT** LOVE. THIS. SAUCE.  I think it's the worchestershire that brings it over the top!  Don't leave out the sugar and use a good brand of ranch dressing (I used Ken's regular ranch.)  I don't think it's too salty if you don't salt the raw chicken first...bone-in chicken changes the taste so I prefer boneless chicken breasts.  I did cut down on the oil a bit. **EDIT**

Wow this was good!  I used the grill basket and saved the marinade to go on top of rice.  I'd like to try it on skewers as well to get more of a grilled taste.  I only used 1 tsp of salt as some suggested and used dried Rosemary, but otherwise I followed the recipe as written.  I'll make this again and again I'm sure.  Thank you!

text:
These were really tender, but considering the number of ingredients in the marinade, I expected them to have more flavor. All I could really taste was the rosemary but some bites also had a bit of a mild sweetness. I used only about half of the sugar, and I'm glad I did, because I know that sugar in a marinade (or BBQ sauce) will make something burn pretty quickly on the grill. I'll probably make them again because my husband liked them. And again, they are VERY tender.

These were good.  Will make again. The ranch flavor isn't too overpowering so it isn't like you're just dipping chicken fingers into ranch, which is a good thing.  It was too cold out for grilling so I put them in the oven to broil.  I also marinated some grape tomatoes and pieces of yellow bell peppers in worcestershire sauce and threaded them on as well for some color and extra flavor.

text:
I cut chicken breasts into strips and marinated for 2 hours and these were AWESOME.  Grill on High for 3 minute, turn and grill the other side 3 more minutes and then turn it down low for another 3 or until the internal temp reaches 180.  This will be a regular in our house going forward.  (Note - i took the suggestion of others and decreased the oil and made ranch from a packet to lower the fat using olive oil mayo and lower fat milk)

country:
None
text:
Most tender chicken I've ever made. Ready in no time at all and very flavorful. Put a grape tomato or some veggie in the middle of each piece of chicken to ensure not to crowd the chicken too close together.  If chicken too close together, they take longer to cook or, like in my case once, didn't get cooked all the way and I had to put some of the pieces back on the grill.

text:
My son would give this a 5 but he isn't posting so I am giving it a 4. He thought it was the best chicken he had ever eaten. I thought it was very tasty. I made a couple of changes. I used 1/2 olive oil, 1/2 canola. Canola has a slightly higher smoke point and I don't use my expensive olive oil for grilling, I save it for dishes where I can taste the flavor of the oil. Also, I did not add salt, I felt that is way too much salt for any dish and the ranch already had enough salt in it. I will be making this next weekend for a family gathering. Thanks!

Definitely five stars!  This chicken is so good!  I made it how written once, and also used blue agave nectar instead of sugar the other time and you can't tell the difference.  I used Costco's one and only Greg's ranch and it was delicious.  It's now our favorite chicken marinade!  We didn't use skewers, just put them on the grill.  Also, when I put the chicken in the marinade i jabbed the chicken with forks so the marinade would soak into the chicken.  Also used garlic salt instead of salt.   So moist! Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
6807235
Display Name:
hughescd1
isPro:
False

0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hesitated to make this recipe.  I was afraid that the ranch flavor would be over powering but it was not.  The flavor of this chicken was excellent!!  It is my husbands favorite chicken dish now. 

MY TIPS:  I used dried rosemary leaves as I had no fresh on hand and it was delicious!  I pounded my chicken breast  very thin and marinated it for about 3 hours.  Pounding the chicken thin is key.  It takes up the flavors wonderfully.  I didn't skewer mine.  I just grilled the chicken breasts as is.

Negative: Add the remaining marinade to the rice sparingly.  It can be a bit strong.
Review:

5

text:
Only two stars for this recipe. It was easy to prepare and I had all the ingredients on hand. I did not make the kabobs but instead marinated and then baked boneless chicken breasts. Otherwise, I followed the recipe.  The chicken was nice and moist and I did like the rosemary a lot. The family said it was 'okay'. The sauce, mediocre in flavor, was off-colored beige and not visually appetizing. Therefore the two stars.  I might try this again (it never hurts to give something another go) but I will grill it as the recipe states and see if that makes enough of a difference to keep this recipe on hand.  Thanks for posting--it is always fun to try new dishes.

text:
This is always a hit whenever I make it and is now a mainstay at the 4th of July bash.  I cut the pounded chicken breasts in tenderloin style strips before marinating, always use chopped fresh rosemary and Ken's buttermilk ranch dressing. The strips are easy to cook on the grill in no time, and IF there are leftovers they're just as good the next day. Even the picky eaters go for this chicken !  I have frozen the marinated strips in a zip-lock bag along with the marinade and this works great too !

I was looking for a good chicken recipe to serve at my cookout. I doubled the recipe and it was just the right amount for 12 chicken breasts. It had a very nice flavor and had a nice aroma as it was being grilled.

text:
This recipe is definitely a keeper!  Like others, I didn't add any salt and only used two tablespoons of Worchestershire.  I used Ken's ranch dressing (full fat) and the flavors came together perfectly.  I'm glad I cut back on the Worchestershire though since it would have masked the ranch.  I marinated the cubed chicken in a ziplock for 10 hours before skewering and grilling.  They came out juicy and delicious.  Served with roasted asparagus and fingerling potatoes with rosermary from AR.  I'm looking forward to adding this to our summer grilling routine.

userID:
4695969
Display Name:
lshaw

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7085211.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not too many ingredients and yet very pleasing flavor from the marinade combination.  The chicken remains tender provided you don't over cook it.  I never seem to do much outside grilling so I frequently cook dishes like this on a long griddle on my stovetop, which works just fine this way.
Caution:  Due to the sugar in the marinade, be careful the chicken pieces do not burn.  Chicken pieces should have some caramelization or golden brown color, but not blackened!  Neither does a too-white color make the best presentation. Turn skewers frequently to avoid burning and get good coloring.  Take off grill or stove immediately to avoid toughening or burning once cooked.

text:
Oh my gosh...fantastic!! A few minor changes but not many! I bought fresh chicken 'tenders' rather than regular breasts. I do not like to cut it all up & skewer it. The tenders are SO moist, & easy and they are already in fairly small pieces and cook up really quickly. Worked great!  I cut back on the salt and used maybe 1t or so. Added a quick dash of onion powder and garlic powder. I did not find it to be too sweet with the sugar in it. It was a BIG hit with guests tonight! You will love this...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding! I marinated 5 boneless chicken breasts, rather than kabobs, overnight and grilled them on a low setting on the gas grill for about 12-15 minutes on each side, checking the internal temp periodically until the thermometer registered 175 degrees.  I removed the breasts from the grill and allowed them to rest for about 6 minutes before serving. The result was a very moist, tender product.  The next day for lunch, I warmed up a leftover chicken breast, sliced it and added to an ice cold tossed salad.  Wonderful!

This was a very good and easy recipe.  I used chicken breasts that were pre-seasoned (in the package) and added the marinade to the already seasoned chicken breasts.  Wonderful flavor, but would use boneless, skinless chicken thighs the next time, as the chicken breasts tend to dry out, even when not overcooked.  All in all, excellent recipe, will definately make again.

text:
I made this dish, but made some changes because we are on Weight Watchers. I completely left out the oil, sugar and prepared ranch dressing. Instead, I used a half cup of lowfat buttermilk, probably a half of a Ranch dressing MIX packet and then added the lemon, vinegar and fresh rosemary, pepper, less salt and less Worchestershire sauce and I also added one minced garlic clove.. I marinated it for probably three hours and then grilled on skewers with veggies. It was very tasty and everyone loved it!

text:
With the first bite to 'test if it's done', the boyfriends eyes nearly popped out of his head.  It's that good.  I'm afraid of grilling chicken because it usually dries out, but this recipe promises moist chicken and it SERIOUSLY delivers! We didn't use the rosemary because we don't like it (nor did I feel like buying a huge pack for a tablespoon's worth - if you have a good friend that grows some, I recommend kissing butt for a sprig ;) ).  I threw in 2 pinches of thyme leaves as a replacement.  Made a little extra sauce and served over rice (cooked it a little bit since the chicken sat in it), and served it up with some grilled corn (butter, salt and pepper wrapped up in aluminum foil).  Fabulous.  The fiance said THIS HAS TO MAKE IT INTO OUR RECIPE BOX.  *Update* Skewered this with some onions then grilled and threw on top of a salad with Mama's Balsamic Vinagrette which paired p e r f e c t l y with it.  Awesome!

My whole family loved this!!  I used exact ingredients listed. I used 1 lb. of cubed chicken. Very easy and good. Scaled the recipe for 2, but I would add more roesmary than the 1 tsp the scaled recipe called for.  Seemed to make the chicken a bit mushy, but I did marinate it for longer than recommended (it was too nice an evening on the deck to leave it to cook!) Will make again, adding a bit more rosemary and maybe some garlic.
8/7/10 update Made this again and added garlic and more rosemary. Really tasty; 4 1/2 stars.  One other reviewer mentioned it lacked punch; maybe a dash of Tabasco next time. Still, a keeper and will definitely be a go-to recipe. Also made a batch of marinade just for the vegs - onion, red pepper, yellow and green zucchini and mushrooms.

This marinade is great! Be sure to use fresh rosemary (I made it with dried and fresh and the fresh is definately better!) I also tried it with the buttermilk ranch and the regular ranch and I prefer the regular ranch.  I also added 3 cloves of garlic and marinated it overnight I cut the worchestershire sauce in half the second time I made it I felt the salt dried it out when marinated overnight I also did not add the sugar the second time it caramalized too much on the grill Everyone gobbled these up on mother's day and everyone asked for the recipe

This is really good and easy.  Our grill was out of commission, so I marinated whole chicken breasts and baked them for 20 minutes at 350.  It was really good-my husband loved it as well.  I followed the recipe to a T, except I used soy sauce instead of Worcestershire because that's what I had on hand.  I also halfed the recipe, because I was making it for 2 people.  I will definitely make this again--I can't wait to try it on the grill!  EDIT: I finally made this as kabobs on the grill--amazing!  I love it before, but its even better now.  I followed the recipe exactly, except I marinaded the chicken for 6 hours.  On the skewers I put red pepper, onion and potatoes (unmarinaded, but I seasoned the potatoes).  This is an amazing dish that I will make again and again.

text:
I gave this a four because my boyfriend (who loves everything) loved this recipe, but for me (being a picky eater) thought it was okay.  The chicken was definitely really moist and overall had good flavor - perhaps I'm just not big on rosemary.  I will definitely try this again though.  I did make a few changes.  Because there were only two of us I used two chicken breast halves (made about 6 kabobs-plenty).  I used canola oil (all I had), about 3/4 cup of ranch, 2 tsp lemon juice, 2 tsp vinegar, 2 tsp garlic powder.  The rest of the ingredients I kept the same as the original 6 serving recipe.  I marinated the chicken for about 2 hours then alternated chicken pieces and pieces of green pepper on the skewers.  Overall pretty good recipe and very easy (which is always good in my book).

text:
This is delicious! My whole family (My husband, 4 kids, and me) loved this chicken! I made it exactly as written, but left it in the fridge to marinate for about 4 hours until dinner. I read a lot of reviews before cooking it, and tripled the sauce recipe, but that wasn't needed. I think double would have been perfect. Thw reviewers that comment on not liking rosemary or it was ovewhelming...make sure you use FRESH rosemary as the recipe calls for. The dry bottled stuff always tastes awful and most people use way too much. If you can't use fresh, then all you would need is a pinch of the dry stuff. Anyway...everyone loved this in my house...and it was even better the next day:) Thanks for a great recipe! We will definitely have it again!

country:
None
text:
These were oddly on the oily side, but other than that they tasted awesome. We had a few feet of snow, so I oven baked rather than grilled for 20 mins in a 375 degree oven. I placed them in a shallow pan and poured all of the excess marinade into the bottom. Very moist and flavorful, just a bit oily. Plenty of flavors, so go ahead and omit ALL that extra salt! You won't miss it. I will reduce the oil next time and I can't wait until I can try them off of the grill! The leftovers never even hit the microwave the next day because they tasted so good cold!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for my 23rd birthday party and they went over really well. I gave some to my bro because, as a broke college student with a half kitchen, he never eats any real food. I used 3 tbl Margarita mix instead of lemon juice and sugar (x2 because I doubled the recipie). People liked the lime-y taste. Joe helped and cut the chicken up while I mixed the marinade. I cut the skewers in half and baked the chicken in the oven in a casserole dish. I used tinfoil to protect the dish but I didn't do a very good job so it didn't work. For the first half hour I cooked the dish at 400 degrees with tinfoil on top but it was still pretty juicy so I cooked it another 15 min on 550 and the top layer browned a little. I took off the top layer served it, drained the juice out and cooked the bottom layer for another 10 minutes at 550. They browned pretty well after that but the dish was a bitch to clean in the end.

These are sooo good... I followed the recipe exactly except I marinated them over night and while I was at work. When I got home I skewered them on wooden skewers and grilled them on the george foreman grill. They turned out really good. I only put five chicken chunks on each skewer and could only grill three at a time but they didn't take long to cook. I did have to move the chiken around and turn it so they wouldn't burn, they got very crispy in some parts... So good will make again and again Loved these!!

This was absolutely fabulous.  I usually follow recipes to a T the first time I make them, but I was short on Worcestershire sauce, so I substituted steak seasoning in its place.  Also, I didn't have 30 minutes to let the chicken sit in the marinade, so I sealed it all up in a FoodSaver bag for 15 minutes instead.  It was VERY GOOD!

text:
Pretty darned good :-) I followed the recipe exactly (except I extended the marinading time to 5 hours and soaked the skewers in water for 30 minutes before grilling so they wouldn't catch fire), and threw them on the grill next to veggie kabobs made with red onion, zucchini, and cherry tomatoes (I marinaded the veggie kabobs in italian dressing for 5 hours as well).  Then, I whipped up some rice pilaf and presto -- we had a lovely dinner.  Thanks for the recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/216167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SOO good! I loved this recipe. I made no changes to the actual marinade for the chicken but I doubled it and put the rest of it over chopped red potatoes, summer squash, and green beans. I also added to them garlic powder, red pepper, bread crumbs, and parmesan cheese sprinkled on top. I roasted just the potatoes first for an hour and then added the squash and green beans for another half hour to 45 min. I covered the dish with foil for the entire time except the last half hour and baked it at 425. It was the perfect blend! The only complaint my family had was that there wasn't more and we are a very critical family when it comes to food. Everyone loved it and I can't wait to make it again. It was so easy to make!

Made the marinade as written (except only used 1/2 the amount of salt), cut 3 large chicken breasts into strips & marinated them for 2 hours.  Since it is snowing here (IN APRIL...arrrg), I lined a cookie sheet w/aluminum foil & broiled the strips for about 8 minutes on each side.  LOVED the result!  My extremely picky father even commented that the taste of the chicken was excellent.  Thank you for a great recipe, will FOR SURE make again!

text:
When I first made the marinade and tasted it I was really nervous because it didn't taste too great. But I went ahead and put the chicken in it overnight. The next evening I tossed some peppers and mushrooms in some extra sauce I'd set aside, and put the chicken and veggies on the skewers. I broiled the kabobs for 8-10 minutes, turning once, and they turned out great. The only change I made to the recipe was I used only about half the salt it called for.

text:
UPDATE: MY NEIGHBOR RECENTLY DESCRIBED A PORK DISH SHE ROUTINELY MAKES THAT MADE ME CRAVE THIS RECIPE. THERE IS MUCH TO BE SAID FOR FOLLOWING A RECIPE EXACTLY AS INTENDED AT LEAST ONCE. THESE ARE FANTASTIC IF GRILLED (DO NOT BAKE - IF IT'S TOO COLD TO GRILL, WAIT UNTIL WARM WEATHER RETURNS!). IT'S A SHAME I DIDN'T FIND THIS OUT THE FIRST TIME. Hmmm.... These were allright. A bit tangy for my liking, but decent nonetheless. As a few others have also done, I too baked my kabobs at 350 degrees for 30 minutes (I soaked my wooden skewers in water all day so they'd be safe for oven use). I liked the idea of drizzling some of the cooked marinade over rice as someone suggested, but unfortunately I wasn't a fan. I think I'll give these another try, but will grill or broil my kabobs instead (I think this is the way to go). Thanks anyways, Theresa! :-)

text:
I don't have a grill so I had to change it up a bit to make in the oven.  I marinated the chicken for about four hours and then baked them with baby bella mushrooms, onions, and zucchini (which I also marinated for a while, as well).  I had soaked the skewers in water for a couple hours and then baked it all at 450 for 10 minutes or so, and then turned them and cooked for another 10-15 minutes.  They came out really well! I served it with garlic and olive oil couscous, and they went well together.  My boyfriend really liked this recipe and I'm sure we'll use it again.

text:
This marinade is fantastic! I've made several times and will continue to make over and over.  While this works well with whole chicken breasts or boneless breasts I would definitely recommend making theese as kabobs, they really soak up the great flavor of the marinade better this way and come out absolutely scrumptious off the grill... also I've had good luck with letting the kabobs sit in the marinade for up to 24 hours.  I've made this with dried rosemary if I didn't have any fresh on hand and it still comes out great. I also agree with the reviewer that suggested Trader Joe's ranch dressing, it really is the best.  Thanks for this wonderful recipe!!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2008-08-26T06:53:27.84
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
2366371
Display Name:
AmyC
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just have to add my two cents about this great recipe! When I made the marinade the first time, I wasn't so sure about it. However, I had read the reviews and knew that others had the same thought, but I also knew that those same people thought the recipe was great. I've made it at least five times now, and it's always been amazing. The first time I just marinated whole chicken breasts for a couple hours and grilled them using dried rosemary instead of fresh because that's all I had. I also omitted the salt thinking it wasn't really necessary. The second time I made them as kabobs and used the fresh rosemary -- a definite must!!! -- just a pinch of salt, and brown sugar instead of white. I also marinated vidalia onion, red pepper, and mushrooms in a separate bowl and added that to the kabobs as well as fresh pineapple. Oh man, they were to die for! I heated the marinade from the veggies to serve over rice which everyone but me has just loved. It has a bit of a tang to it that I just don't prefer with rice. I served the kabobs with a 5-blend rice, tossed veggie salad and fresh fruit. It's a great summer meal! The last three times I've made it we've had company, and everyone (even the picky eaters and kids) have loved it and asked for the recipe. Thanks for a really great recipe!! 

Just a note: although using dried rosemary still makes it taste great, using fresh rosemary makes it even better. So if you can get fresh do so :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-08-24T11:36:12.09

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!These kabobs were delicious! The marinade provided great flavor, and also made the chicken extremely tender and moist. I marinated the chicken for about 1.5 hours, meanwhile, soaking bamboo skewers in water. For the marinade, I used Hidden Valley Ranch and dried rosemary, which worked fine. The only changes I will make next time is to try fresh rosemary and CHOP it into little pieces (pieces of rosemary kept getting stuck in our teeth!), and save a little of the marinating liquid before adding the chicken to use as a basting/dipping sauce. Grilled on medium heat on a gas grill for ten minutes (lid closed), turning once. Make sure you do not forget to oil the grill grate, otherwise the kabobs will stick horribly!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This marinade is much too delicious to waste.  Used four large boneless chicken breasts, cut them in half and marinated them in the sauce for about 45 min.  Meanwhile I put some rice in the rice cooker and sauted some vidalia onion, sliced mushrooms, yellow squash,diced mushrooms and peppers in a little EVOO. Add some pepper & extra rosemary to the veggies. I added the veggies to the chicken and marinade and baked in the oven covered for about 45 min.  The chicken was tender and the sauce delicious over rice.  I'll definitely make this again.  Next time I would cut back a little on the salt in the marinade.

text:
This recipe was a hit with my family! The chicken really does come out tender and juicy.  I cooked mine in an electric oven under the broiler and used a broiler pan.  The marinade was a bit thick, so I whisked in a few tablespoons of water before I poured it into the drip pan. After I cooked the kabobs 10 minutes per side, I poured the drippings and marinade over brown rice and it was excellent!! The one thing I'll do differently nex time I make this dish is to soak my bamboo skewers in cold water before I roast the chicken. I could barely smell the delicious food over the stench of burning wood!!

text:
I almost never have all the ingredients listed for the recipes and have to "alter" a bit, besides am always adding stuff to "make it my own" That said, this is really very flavorful and the chicken came out very tender. I didn't have ranch "dressing"(wet) but had the HVR dry dressing(used a half pack) and had to substitute the olive oil for what I had on hand (vegetable oil). Also eliminated the 2 tsp. salt(I thought the dry ranch dressing would be salty enough) and added 1 tsp. garlic powder and added more black pepper and some crushed red pepper flakes- we like it on the spicy side. Delicious! Will def be making it again! Thanks for sharing

text:
Four and a half stars - I thought these were excellent, but my husband (who likes things "plain") wasn't thrilled, but said they were ok.  I marinated the chicken for about 4 hours before grilling and the result was very tender, melt-in-your-mouth chicken.  And don't listen to my husband - I thought the flavor from the marinade was very subtle, but enough to give it a little something.  I did probably use slightly less rosemary than what was called for - I just used up what I had so it was about 3/4 tbsp.  I'll definitely make these again!

Very good.  I used this with whole boneless, skinless chicken breasts because I was too lazy to cut them and skewer them.  I marinated for about 1.5 hours and then grilled on the foreman. This was terrific! Didn't marinate any veggies with it, but would definitely do so next time. Marinated about 3-4 hours and had outstanding flavor. Can cut back or omit salt - I didn't this time but will next - there's plenty of sodium in the Worchestershire! Fresh rosemary is key, and no need for sugar. We grilled, and I think this made it, but baking would probably be okay for the winter months. Hubby and I thought it would make a good chicken sandwich w/some provolone or other cheese, too. Or cut up on a salad. Kids gobbled it up, too. Great flavor!

userID:

Display Name:
Brynne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was really nervous when I smelled the marinade for this dish - it smelled like nothing but ranch dressing.  Don't get me wrong - I like ranch dressing well enough, but I feared that it would make my chicken really tangy.  It even freaked me out enough that I doctored it a little, adding cajun spice and chili powder.  I was pleasantly surprised!  It didn't taste like ranch dressing at all.  I didn't make skewers - I marinated whole chicken breasts, adding about 2x the amount of dried rosemary (didn't have fresh), cajun spice and chili powder.  I marinated for about an hour. I then grilled the whole chicken breast in a cast iron pan, basting with the marinade throughout.  I also threw a few whole crimini mushrooms in the marinade and then around the periphery of the pan.  The end result was a grilled chicken with a very nicely-flavored glaze, and the crimini mushrooms were the best.  I would do it exactly the same way next time.
Review:
